Although different Salafis emphasized different aspects of the broad reformist project, all of the factions coexisted and coalesced under the leadership of Rida, who channeled all the tendencies through ""Al-Manar"" and his scholarly involvement in public affairs. After Rida's death in 1935, the advocates of "Salafiyya" began to fragment and coalesced around four major movements—<a href="Islamic%20modernism">Modernism</a>, <a href="Islamism">Islamism</a>, <a href="Salafi%20movement%23Purists">Purism</a> and <a href="Jihadism">Jihadism</a>— often competing for dominance and making rival claims to orthodoxy. Over the course of decades, most of the disciples of Rida drifted towards religious purism. Roughly a decade after Rida's death in Cairo, the epicenter of "Salafiyya" had moved nearer to <a href="Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>. In a letter sent by the prominent Salafi scholar <a href="Muhammad%20Bahjat%20Athari">Muhammad Bahjat al-Bitar</a> from Saudi Arabia in 1947, to the Moroccan scholar <a href="Muhammad%20Taqi-ud-Din%20al-Hilali">Taqi-ud-Din Al-Hilali</a> - both former pupils of Rida - ; Al-Bitar would praise <a href="Abdulaziz%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">Ibn Saud</a> for his contributions to <a href="Islamic%20revival">Islamic revival</a>ism and refer to him as "the leader of the Salafiyya"("imām al-daʿwa al-salafiyya"). With their institutional capabilities, control of the Islamic holy cities, rejection of popular <a href="Sufism">Sufism</a> and official championing of the reformist cause, the political and religious authorities of Saudi Arabia, had attained credible prospects to claim the leadership of "<a href="Salafi%20movement">Salafiyya</a>" movement.
Eventually, out of all currents competing between Rida's successors, a Purist notion of "Salafiyya" supported by the Saudi "ulema" would emerge dominant. This came to be emphasized globally as the "Salafi Manhaj". "Manhaj" refers to the path or methodology by which Salafis live and implement their beliefs and "Da'wa"(call). This "Manhaj" was associated with the Syrian-Albanian Islamic scholar <a href="Muhammad%20Nasiruddin%20al-Albani">Muhammad Nasiruddin Al-Albani</a>, considered as one of the leading authorities for Salafis globally. Alongside Albani, <a href="Muhammad%20ibn%20al-Uthaymeen">Muhammad ibn Salih al Uthaymeen</a> and <a href="Abd%20al-Aziz%20ibn%20Baz">Ibn Baz</a> became the main advocates of the "Salafi Manhaj". The "Salafi Manhaj" was opposed to two other competing camps: 1) <a href="Salafi%20jihadism">Jihadi-Salafism</a> which was heavily influenced by the <a href="Qutbism">thought of Sayyid Qutb</a> 2) "Salafi-harakis", i.e., Activist Salafis or <a href="Islamism">Islamists</a> who advocated non-violent political activism in Muslim and non-Muslim countries. Starting from the 1980s, Purist Salafis would distinguish themselves from the emerging counter-currents. Toeing this line, contemporary Salafis portray Rashid Rida as a "true Salafi in the Taymiyyan and Wahhabi traditions".
Differences from Early "Salafiyya".
Contemporary <a href="Salafi%20movement%23Purists">Purist Salafism</a>, widely known as "the Salafi Manhaj" emerged from the 1960s as an intellectual hybrid of three similar, yet distinct, religious reform traditions: the <a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabi</a> movement in Arabia, "<a href="Ahl-i%20Hadith">Ahl-i Hadith</a>" movement in India and "Salafiyya" movement in the Arab World of the late-19th and early 20th centuries. The person most responsible for this transformation was the Syrian Islamic scholar <a href="Muhammad%20Nasiruddin%20al-Albani">Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani</a>, who is considered to be the "spiritual father" of the Purist Salafi current and recognised by all contemporary Salafis as "the greatest hadith scholar of his generation". Albani's school of thought differed from his teachers of the "Salafiyya" tradition in three major ways:
Later Years.
The "<a href="Modernist%20Salafism">Enlightenment Salafism</a>" of <a href="Jamal%20al-Din%20al-Afghani">Jamal al-Din Afghani</a> and <a href="Muhammad%20Abduh">Muhammad 'Abduh</a> did not partake of the literalist theology of <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya</a>. Rather, Abduh and Afghani were rationalist <a href="Ash%27ari">Ash'ari</a>s. The Abduh-Afghani school, however, was similar to Ibn Taymiyya and <a href="Ibn%20Qayyim%20al-Jawziyya">Ibn Qayyim</a> on legal principles such as importance of "<a href="Ijtihad">Ijtihad</a>" to interpret textual sources. However, they weren't literalists and did not promote unconditional authority of "<a href="hadith">hadith</a>s". After the death of his mentor Abduh, Rashid Rida moved closer to traditional Salafi teachings and was seriously involved in editing and publishing of works of Ibn Taymiyya and like-minded scholars. Throghout his writings in "<a href="Al-Man%C4%81r%20%28magazine%29">Al-Manar</a>" and other works, he began espousing traditional Salafi legal and theological positions. Scholars such as Muhammad Hamid al-Fiqi drew Rida closer to the scholars of <a href="Najd">Najd</a> and away from the rationalism of Abduh. Rida, adopting a Hadith-centric approach in his methodology would also associate with the "<a href="Ahl-i%20Hadith">Ahl-i-Hadith</a>" movement of the <a href="Indian%20subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>. Rida and "Ahl-i-Hadith" scholars would co-publish books propagating Salafi principles.
Advocacy of Wahhabism.
Rashid Rida developed favourable views towards <a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabis</a> upon his arrival in <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> in the 1890s; after reading about the movement in the histories of <a href="Abd%20al-Rahman%20al-Jabarti">Al-Jabartī</a> and <a href="Ahmad%20ibn%20Khalid%20al-Nasiri">Al-Nāṣiri</a>. Thus, as early as 1900s, Rashid Rida had hailed Ibn Saud's victories during the <a href="Saudi%E2%80%93Rashidi%20War%20%281903%E2%80%931907%29">Saudi-Rashidi wars</a>. A few years before Abduh's death, the term “"Salafiyya"” discretely found its way into Rashid Rida's seminal journal "<a href="Al-Man%C4%81r%20%28magazine%29">Al-Manār</a>". At first, Rida understood the word in a narrow theological sense and used it as an adjective that characterized the unique creed of the pious ancestors ("ʿaqīda" "wāḥida" "salafiyya"), which he openly equated with <a href="Hanbali%20school%20of%20Islamic%20theology">Hanbali theology</a>. In a 1913 article, he declared that <a href="Najd">Najd</a>, the heart of today's Saudi Arabia, was the region in which Salafi theology was the most widespread. However, during this stage, Rida had noted that "the Wahhabis were overcome with harshness ("jafāʾ") and exaggeration ("ghuluw") and were not “moderate” like the other Salafis in <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>, the <a href="Hejaz">Hijaz</a>, <a href="Syria%20%28region%29">Greater Syria</a>, and <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>". In Rida's mind, moderation ("iʿtidāl") was a defining characteristic of the school of "Salafiyya".
After the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>, Rashid Rida no longer saw the 'tradition-bound' "<a href="ulama">ulama</a>", but rather, the rising class of <a href="Westernization">Westernizing</a> Muslim intelligentsia as his main opponents. Thus, Rida would became the most enthusiastic stalwart of <a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a>. In 1919, he published <a href="Muhammad%20ibn%20Abd%20al-Wahhab">Muhammad Ibn 'Abd al-Wahhab's</a> "Kashf al-Shubuhat" (Removal of Doubts); and by 1920, Rida had begun extolling ibn ‘Abd al-Wahhab as a "<a href="Mujaddid">Mujadid</a>" of <a href="Islam">Islam</a> in <a href="Najd">Nejd</a>. Were it not for the excessive zeal of some of his supporters, and the conspiracies of his adversaries, Rida argued; the Wahhabi movement could have expanded and led <a href="Islamic%20revival">Islamic revival</a> all across the <a href="Muslim%20world">Islamic World</a>. In 1922 Rashid Rida distributed a volume of essays containing writings by Ibn Taymiyya, Ibn Qudama, and Ibn Rajab; reportedly after payment from a Najdi merchant. This would stir a theological controversy between the Sufi and Salafi factions of Syria. For Rashid Rida, "Salafiyya" came to symbolise religious fervour and puritanical revival of old Islamic practices. The thrust to return to the ways of the pious ancestors ("<a href="Salaf">Salaf</a>") was also combined with doctrines of Arab pre-eminence. This also made him a committed supporter of <a href="Unification%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi military expansions</a> and Wahhabi revival.
By rejecting "<a href="taqlid">taqlid</a>", and going back beyond the founders of the "<a href="Madhhab">Madh'habs</a>" to the early community of the "<a href="Salaf">Salaf</a>", Rashïd Ridā and his followers would gravitate towards the <a href="Hanbali">Hanbali</a>te reformist outlook of <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya</a>, with other scholarly influences like those of <a href="Al-Ghazali">Al-Ghazāli</a> getting rapidly replaced. As the most vocal medieval theologian who condemned <a href="Sufism">Sufi</a> innovations and heresies, Ibn Taymiyya exemplied the most authoritative classical scholar to the "Al-Manar" party. While politically <a href="Pan-Islamism">pan-Islamist</a>, in its social program "Salafiyya" was being increasingly be characterized by Puritanism and was facing opposition from conservative quarters like <a href="Al-Azhar%20University">Al-Azhar</a>. Meanwhile, they found support from other quarters with the revival of Wahhabism in <a href="Arabian%20Peninsula">Arabia</a> and the "<a href="Ahl-i%20Hadith">Ahl-i Hadith</a>" movement in <a href="India">India</a>, all of whom condemned Sufi innovations and saint-cults and looked up to Ibn Taymiyya as the greatest medieval scholar.
Saudi-Hejazi Conflicts.
Following a series of catastrophic events in the <a href="Aftermath%20of%20World%20War%20I">aftermath of the World War</a>, such as the ongoing <a href="Partition%20of%20the%20Ottoman%20Empire">Partition of the Ottoman Empire</a>, the <a href="Franco-Syrian%20War">French occupation of Syria</a> in 1920, the <a href="Mandatory%20Iraq">loss of Iraq</a> and <a href="Mandate%20for%20Syria%20and%20the%20Lebanon">Greater Syria</a> to the Mandatory Powers, the triumph of <a href="Secularism">secular</a> <a href="Kemalism">Kemalists</a> in <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>, the <a href="Abolition%20of%20the%20Ottoman%20sultanate">abolition of the Sultanate</a> and <a href="Abolition%20of%20the%20Caliphate">the caliphate</a> in 1922 and 1924 respectively; Rashid Rida's militant opposition to the <a href="European%20Powers">European powers</a> had reached its peak by the 1920s. He responded to these challenges by proposing a comprehensive <a href="Pan-Islamism">pan-Islamist</a> thesis in his famous book ""<a href="The%20Caliphate%20or%20the%20Grand%20Imamate">al-Khilafa aw al-Imama al-‘Uzma</a>"" (The Caliphate or the Exalted Imamate), published in 1922. He called upon <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a> to rally behind the banners of their shared <a href="Islamic%20faith">Islamic faith</a>; shun the emerging <a href="Nationalism">nationalist</a> currents, and stressed the role of <a href="Arabs">Arab</a> leadership in unifying Muslim ranks. Of utmost importance to his agenda was thwarting <a href="British%20imperialism">British imperialist</a> goals in the <a href="Arabian%20Peninsula">Arabian peninsula</a>. Although he greatly admired <a href="Abdulaziz%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">'Abd al-Aziz</a> and the religiosity of Wahhabis, he urged <a href="Hussein%20bin%20Ali%2C%20Sharif%20of%20Mecca">Sharif Husayn</a> and Ibn Saud not to fight each other as late as 1919, and unite in the face of the colonial threat. Through the pages of "<a href="Al-Man%C4%81r%20%28magazine%29">Al-Manar</a>", Rida regularly called for <a href="Islamic%20Unification%20Movement">Islamic unity</a> against the European threat.
However, Sharif Husayn's rejection of Rida's overtures and his continued privileged relations with the <a href="British%20Empire">British</a> and the <a href="French%20Third%20Republic">French</a> would make Rida publicly condemn Husayn. By the 1920s, Husyan had taken control of <a href="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> with British-backing and his sons <a href="Faisal%20I%20of%20Iraq">Faysal</a> and <a href="Abdullah%20I%20of%20Jordan">Abdallah</a> were granted the <a href="British%20protectorate">Protectorates</a> of <a href="Mandate%20of%20Iraq">Iraq</a> and <a href="Emirate%20of%20Transjordan">Transjordan</a>; respectively. Rashid Rida castigated Sharif Husayn and his sons for their dynastic schemings in collusion with the <a href="colonial%20powers">colonial powers</a> to betray their own people. For Rida, the king of the Hijaz was nothing more than a sellout and a pawn of the British Empire in their oppression of <a href="Arabs">Arabs</a> and <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a>. By 1923, Rida had begun to publicly call upon the Arabian emirs to free Hejaz from the <a href="Hashemites">Hashemite</a> rule. Rida viewed <a href="Abdulaziz%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">Ibn Saud</a> of the <a href="Sultanate%20of%20Nejd">Sultanate of Najd</a> as the most suitable candidate for this task, not only because he favoured the Wahhabis as the best hope for Arab and <a href="Islamic%20renaissance">Islamic renaissance</a>; but also because of their promising military-political capabilities to bring stability and security to the Hijaz, and defend it from any European imperial aggressions. In stark contrast to the Hashemite family, Ibn Saud and his faithful Wahhabi followers were pious Muslims striving to apply orthodoxy and orthopraxy in keeping with the doctrines of the "<a href="Salaf">Salaf al-Salih</a>" and hence the leadership of holy places of Islam was incumbent upon them. Two days after the <a href="Abolition%20of%20the%20Caliphate">Turkish Abolition of Caliphate</a>, Sharif Husayn <a href="Sharifian%20Caliphate">proclaimed</a> himself as <a href="Caliphate">Caliph</a> of Muslims in March 1924, initiating controversy across the <a href="Muslim%20world">Islamic World</a>. Denouncing his proclamation as illegitimate due to his dependence on the British and his betrayal of Muslims, Rida condemned Sharif Husayn's declaration as a desecration of Islam and viewed him as a "<a href="Mulhid">Mulhid</a>" (heretic) who was dangerous to the entire "<a href="Ummah">Ummah</a>".
Saudi Conquest of Hejaz (1924 - 1925).
In the <a href="Arabian%20Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a>, the <a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabi</a> revival led by the expanding <a href="Sultanate%20of%20Nejd">Sultanate of Najd</a> had led to military clashes with the <a href="Hashemites">Hashemite</a> <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Hejaz">Kingdom of Hijaz</a> by 1924. Since the Hashemites also ruled <a href="Mandatory%20Iraq">Iraq</a> and <a href="Emirate%20of%20Transjordan">Transjordan</a>, the struggle for Hijaz assumed <a href="Pan-Arabism">pan-Arab</a> as well as global <a href="Pan-Islamism">pan-Islamic</a> dimensions; due to the significance of the <a href="Holiest%20sites%20in%20Islam">Islamic Holy Cities</a>. Throughout the <a href="Muslim%20world">Islamic World</a>, the <a href="Hussein%20bin%20Ali%2C%20Sharif%20of%20Mecca">Sharīf</a> was regarded with increasing disdain. Rida would wholeheartedly champiom <a href="Abdulaziz%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">'Abdul Aziz Ibn Saud's</a> Hejaz campaigns during 1924-1925 through "Al-Manar", viewing the nascent Saudi state as the best hope for <a href="Islamic%20revival">Islamic Renaissance</a> and portrayed it as the last major bastion of Islamic resistance to the <a href="Colonialism">colonial</a> order. In August 1924, Ibn Sa’ud launched a final, decisive offensive against the <a href="Hejaz">Hijaz</a> and, following his defeat in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Mecca%20%281924%29">Battle of Mecca</a> in December, Husayn was forced to abdicate. Rida enthusiastically welcomed the conquest of Mecca by the Sultanate of Najd, portraying it as a historic event and a long-yearned opportunity for Muslims to recover the lost Islamic glory. Within a few years, 'Abd al-Azeez ibn Saud had united Hejaz and Northern Arabia, gained international recognition and prestige; and his saga had become a success-story and an Islamic alternative to <a href="Mustafa%20Kemal%20Atat%C3%BCrk">Atatürk</a> in <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>. King 'Abd al-'Aziz's greatness, independence, and religiosity combined with his pragmatic promotion of technology to develop his state, exemplied balanced reform to Rashid Rida.
Rashid Rida vocally defended the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Hejaz%20and%20Nejd">new Saudi regime</a> from its Muslim and non-Muslim detractors; proclaiming that the <a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabis</a> were "the best Muslims" who stayed true to the doctrines of "Imam" <a href="Ahmad%20ibn%20Hanbal">Ahmad Ibn Hanbal</a>, one of the four celebrated patronyms of <a href="Sunni%20Islam">Sunni</a> <a href="Madhhab">legal schools</a>, and the well-known Hanbalite reformer <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ahmad ibn Taymiyyah</a>. Making <a href="anti-Shi%27ism">anti-Shi'ism</a> "a major trait of his school", Rida would defend the <a href="Demolition%20of%20al-Baqi">Wahhabi demolition of the shrines of Al-Baqi</a>, and fiercely denounced those <a href="Shi%27Ites">Shi'ites</a> who were outraged by it, condemning them as ""<a href="Rafida">Raafidites</a>"" who were the instruments of <a href="Persians">Persians</a>. Through his articles in "<a href="Al-Man%C4%81r%20%28magazine%29">Al-Manar</a>", Rida hailed the Saudi conquest as a sensational moment in Islamic history, declaring it as:"‘a great, truly great event: the <a href="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> has been conquered by the one and only Sunni-Islamic <a href="Salafi%20movement">Salafi</a> state, and the cradle of Islam has come under its control’... ‘<a href="Islah">Islamic reformation</a> now possesses an armed state that fights heresies’ ("<a href="Bid%CA%BBah">al-bida‘</a>")"
Ibn Saud came to represent everything Rida had expected from a just Muslim "<a href="Sultan">Sultan</a>". He rebutted all the circulating rumours regarding the Wahhabis desecrating graves, slaughtering women and children in their conquests etc.; condemning them as "<a href="British%20propaganda%20during%20World%20War%20I">British propaganda</a>". In reality, Rida clarified, Wahhabis restored Islamic rule to the Holy city of <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a> and guaranteed that Hejaz would not have to go through the oppression of despotic rulers in the future. Praising Ibn Saud as a model Islamic ruler that the post-Ottoman Muslim world needed, Rida wrote:“England feels that one of the greatest dangers to her policy in Arab or Islamic countries is the existence among the Muslims of a strong emir, especially if he believes in his religion, adheres to it, and is backed by a people of true faith, like Ibn Saud and his people".
Great Syrian Revolt (1925 - 1927).
Rida's subsequent political efforts focused on two fronts: campaign for Syrian independence and support for Ibn Sa‘ud's efforts to <a href="Unification%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">unify the Arabian Peninsula</a>. When the <a href="Great%20Syrian%20Revolt">Great Syrian Rebellion</a> broke out in 1925, Rida and the <a href="Syrian%E2%80%93Palestinian%20Congress">Syro-Palestinian Congress</a> provided it full support, with financial backing from the nascent Saudi state. However, by 1927, the rebellion had been crushed and the <a href="Syrian%20nationalism">nationalist</a> factions of Syro-Palestinian Congress parted ways with Rida, seeking compromise with the <a href="British%20Empire">British</a> and <a href="French%20Third%20Republic">French</a>. Rida vehemently objected to this and further strengthened ties to Ibn Saud's government, which he regarded as the only sovereign Islamic government that stood up to the colonial powers and guarded the holiest sites in <a href="Islam">Islam</a>. He was also active in <a href="Pan-Islamism">Pan-Islamist</a> organisations that sought to rally Muslim peoples against the European imperial powers. Fearing the influence of Rashid Rida across the <a href="Muslim%20world">Islamic World</a> and his connections to the Saudis, the <a href="British%20intelligence%20agencies">British Intelligence</a> in <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a> closely followed Rida's activities.
World Islamic Congresses (1926).
As the new ruler of <a href="Hejaz">Hejaz</a>, <a href="Abdulaziz%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">'Abd al-Azeez ibn Saud</a> convened a <a href="Pan-Islamism">Pan-Islamic</a> Congress in <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a> in June–July 1926; with the objectives of international Islamic recognition of <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Hejaz%20and%20Nejd">Saudi rule of Hejaz</a>, consultations on "<a href="Hajj">Hajj</a>" (pilgrimage) services, and also to erase the past reputation of sectarianism associated with the <a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabis</a>. (A few years later, Ibn Saud would wage a military campaign against the <a href="Ikhwan%20revolt">"Ikhwan" rebels</a>, who were notorious for their fanaticism across the <a href="Muslim%20world">Islamic World</a>, signalling the future religious reforms to transpire. Rashid Rida would enthusiastically back their elimination) Rida was the most prominent delegate of the Congress, who was entrusted as the organiser of the conference. Ibn Saud charged Rida with convening the conference on his behalf, drafting the conference protocols and writing the king's opening address. In his private capacity, Rida would also support the stances of Ibn Saud and the Saudi delegates. Earlier, Rida had been an important delegate in the preparatory subcommittee for the 1926 Islamic Congress for <a href="Caliphate">Caliphate</a> held in <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a>, which declared that the Caliphate was still possible. However he was not an active participant in the Cairo Congress itself and considered the organizers to be inefficient; privately predicting doom for the Congress due to its lack of resolve and irreconciliable sectarian-political differences. Meanwhile, Rida was enthusiastic about the Meccan Congress and became its most prominent advocate. Delegates of Islamic religious organisations and Muslim governments across the World attended the Congress. Rida pressed for a collective oath of the Congress delegates, pledging to rid the <a href="Arabian%20Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> of all foreign influences. Far exceeding the initial references of the Congress, Rida also proposed an Islamic Pact ("mithal Islami") between Muslim governments, envisioning the assembly as a precursor to a league of Muslim Nations. However, no significant resolutions could be passed and no subsequent congress in Mecca was ever held due to the prevalence of deep religious, doctrinal and political differences across the Muslim world. Despite this, with prominent figures like <a href="Grand%20Mufti%20of%20Jerusalem">Grand Mufti of Jerusalem</a> <a href="Amin%20al-Husseini">Hajji Amin al-Husseini</a> in attendance, the conference marked the consolidation of the alliance between <a href="Pan-Islamism">Pan-Islamists</a> and the leaders of the new Wahhabi state.
Rida would publish a treatise "The Wahhabis and Hijaz" wherein he set forth the case for Wahhabi rule over Hejaz. The treatise condemned <a href="Hussein%20bin%20Ali%2C%20Sharif%20of%20Mecca">Sharif Husayn</a> and his <a href="Hashemites">family</a> for their selling of <a href="Arab%20world">Arab lands</a> in complicity with the agenda <a href="colonial%20powers">colonial powers</a>; for the sake of their personal dynastic ambitions. Rida warned in his treatise about the <a href="Divide%20and%20rule">British manipulations</a> across the region to dominate the region and subjugate <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a>. Defending the religious credentials of Wahhabis, Rashid Rida cited "Tarikh Najd", a treatise composed by <a href="Abdullah%20bin%20Muhammad%20Al%20Sheikh">'Abd Allah ibn Muhammad Aal-al Shaykh</a>, the son of <a href="Muhammad%20ibn%20Abd%20al-Wahhab">Muhammad Ibn 'Abd al Wahhab</a>. He asserted that Wahhabis had sincere zeal for the Islamic faith and were amongst the most hostile to foreign influences. Rida presented their leader Ibn Saud as the strongest and the most capable Islamic leader who would stand up to the <a href="British%20Empire">British imperial</a> programme. The notion that <a href="Western%20world">Western powers</a> colluded with their Arab client-states to dominate Muslim lands and secularise them would become a pillar of subsequent <a href="Islamic%20revival">Islamic revival</a>ist movements. The oldest and most influential of these movement would be the "<a href="Muslim%20Brotherhood">Ikhwan al-Muslimeen</a>" (Muslim Brotherhood), founded by the <a href="Egyptians">Egyptian</a> school teacher <a href="Hassan%20al-Banna">Hasan al-Banna</a> in 1928, who was influenced by Rashid Rida's ideas.
Rehabilitation of Wahhabis.
Although Rida defended the Wahhabis passionately, he had often acknowledged the adverse effects of <a href="Najd">Najd</a>i zeal and acknowledged the existence of fierce exaggerators ("ghulat") amongst the Najdis and their zealotry due to general state of "Jahl" (ignorance). However, he strove to downplay their importance by stressing that King Abd al-Aziz was a reasonable man. In Rida's view, it was better to judge the Najdis based on their pragmatic and moderate political leader or to accept the fact that some fanaticism was better for the "<a href="Ummah">Ummah</a>" than the erosion of <a href="Islamic%20identity">Islamic identity</a>. While he acknowledged the religious militancy of the Najdis, he considered their attitude to be better than the resignation and undeclared defeatism of other <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a>. Even though he defended the Wahhabi movement against its critiques and despite his embracal of Hanbali legal principles, he had found his Hanbali counterparts in Saudi Arabia to be unaware of modern developments, a point that he conveyed to them.
As an exponent of <a href="Traditionalist%20theology%20%28Islam%29">Athari theology</a>, Rida had argued that allegorical interpretations of the scriptures ("<a href="Esoteric%20interpretation%20of%20the%20Quran">ta'wil</a>") were sometimes appropriate because without them many Muslims would have abandoned their religion. Due to pressures of the modern era; the message of <a href="Islam">Islam</a> needed to be articulated in a way that was consistent with <a href="Science">scientific</a> discourses. He took it upon himself to counsel the Najdi scholars on the necessity of balanced <a href="Islah">reform</a> and mailed them copies of "<a href="Tafsir%20al-Manar">Tafsir al-Manar</a>" for learning. In a letter addressed to <a href="Abdul-Rahman%20al-Sa%27di">Abdul Rahman al Sa'adi</a> (d. 1957), the teacher of the famous Salafi scholar <a href="Muhammad%20ibn%20al-Uthaymeen">Ibn 'Uthaymin</a> (d. 2001), Rida advised:"It is necessary that you distinguish between natural sciences, which we invite [people] to learn, and philosophy, both ancient and modern. Philosophy consists of opinions and theoretical thoughts whereas natural sciences are an expression of the science by which God gave benefits to His creation, such as water, steam, air ..., the advantages of electricity -which include the telegraph, the telephone, and more- as well as amazing products like war machines for the land, the sea, and the sky."
When news of <a href="https%3A//ar.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/%25D9%2585%25D8%25AD%25D9%2585%25D8%25AF_%25D8%25A8%25D9%2586_%25D8%25A8%25D9%2584%25D9%258A%25D9%2587%25D8%25AF">Ibn Bulayhid</a>, a Najdi scholar who clashed with Rida's Salafi disciples in <a href="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> over the former's beliefs in , were spreading, Rida sought to control damaging rumours. Other prominent Wahhabi scholars such as <a href="https%3A//ar.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/%25D9%2585%25D8%25AD%25D9%2585%25D8%25AF_%25D8%25A8%25D9%2586_%25D8%25B9%25D8%25A8%25D8%25AF_%25D8%25A7%25D9%2584%25D9%2584%25D8%25B7%25D9%258A%25D9%2581_%25D8%25A8%25D9%2586_%25D8%25B9%25D8%25A8%25D8%25AF_%25D8%25A7%25D9%2584%25D8%25B1%25D8%25AD%25D9%2585%25D9%2586_%25D8%25A2%25D9%2584_%25D8%25A7%25D9%2584%25D8%25B4%25D9%258A%25D8%25AE">Muhammad ibn 'Abd al-Latif Al al-Shaykh</a> would intervene on behalf of Rida's disciples and refute Ibn Bulayhid to affirm the <a href="Spherical%20Earth">sphericity of earth</a>. In an "<a href="Al-Man%C4%81r%20%28magazine%29">Al-Manar</a>" article about education and the dangers of stagnation, Rida criticized flat-earthers and enemies of science. He insisted that the scholars of Najd could not be counted among these ignoramuses and that rumors to the contrary verged on absurdity:
"It has come to my ears that one of the most revered and well-read ulama of Najd advocated anathema [takfir] against anyone who professes that the earth is round. This has startled me because Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab, the imam of the Najdi revival, as well as other scholars [of this movement], have stipulated that they do not accuse anyone of being an infidel except for a breach of consensus about definite religious questions. But this is not a religious question, and there is no [religious] consensus about it. [This has also startled me] because the greatest Hanbali Imams from whose books the shaykh [Muhammad ibn 'Abd al-Wahhab] and his successors derived [their] Najdi religious renewal are Ibn Taymiyya and Ibn Qayyim. The latter has mentioned, in some of his books, that the earth is round. So, if the rumor about this [Najdi] scholar were true, would he charge [Ibn Qayyim] with unbelief?"
However, by 1926, any references to the "excessive zeal" of some of the Wahhabis had disappeared. The initial failure of the <a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabi</a> movement was blamed on the corrupt <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottomans</a> and on the plots of “the country of the Satanic ruses” (i.e. the <a href="British%20Empire">British empire</a>). Saluting <a href="Muhammad%20ibn%20Abd%20al-Wahhab">Ibn ‘Abd al-Wahhab</a> as “the "<a href="Mujaddid">Mujaddid</a>" of the twelfth century” who taught the people of <a href="Najd">Najd</a> the proper understanding of "<a href="Tawhid">Tawḥīd</a>" as expounded by <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya</a>, Rida hailed his movement as one of "reform and renewal" ("al-iṣlāḥ waʾl-tajdīd"). He implored the followers of his "<a href="Islah">Islah</a>" Movement to support the Wahhabis against the three hazards that threatened the "<a href="Ummah">Ummah</a>" from within: i) the “<a href="Shia%20Islam">Shi‘a</a> fanatics”; ii) the "grave-worshippers” (i.e., the <a href="Sufism">Sufis</a>) and iii) the “<a href="Westernization">Westernised</a> preachers of <a href="atheism">atheism</a>". Wahhabi "<a href="Ulama">ulema</a>" would directly collaborate with Rida to publish their works through Rida's "<a href="Al-Man%C4%81r%20%28magazine%29">Al-Manar</a>" publishing house. During the 1920s, "Al-Manar" would publish over two dozen Wahhabi works, which included "<a href="fatwa">fatwa</a>s" refuting the "<a href="Ikhwan">Ikhwan</a>". Most notably, Rida would compile the famous collection of texts titled "Majmūʿat al-rasāʾil waʾl-masāʾil al-Najdiyya" (“The Compendium of Najdī Epistles and Responsa”); and publish it in <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a> as four volumes.
By 1927, throwing his adversaries off-balance, Rida asserted that "Wahhabis" had become a large group in <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, with adherents among the religious scholars of <a href="Al-Azhar%20University">Al-Azhar University</a> and other religious institutions; assisted by the popularity of "<a href="Islah">Islah</a>i" ideals of "al-Manar". Openly claiming that his journal promoted a "Wahhabi" approach to <a href="Islam">Islam</a> was a bold and ironic way of siding with the Najdis while making the point that they did not deserve to be stigmatized. Rida had already started to adopt some of the Wahhabis' more uncompromising attitudes to religious reform. Rida's opponents accused that his transformation to be the official spokesman for the Wahhabites was due to the financial assistance he received from Ibn Saud. However, Rida justified himself by stating that it was his scholarly research and extensive knowledge, that propelled him to defend Wahhabism.
Reformed "Wahhabism".
Despite the mixed results of the rehabilitation campaign and the difficulties that some of his disciples encountered, Rida remained devoted to King <a href="Abdulaziz%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz</a> until the very end. For all his occasional faults, the Saudi ruler was, in the eyes of Rida, the best available Muslim statesman, and his kingdom offered the best prospect of becoming the political arm of the balanced "<a href="Islah">Islah</a>i" movement. Past experience had made Rida recognise the realistic difficulties of putting his ideal reformist efforts into practice: it required money as well as political support. The strong relationship between Riḍā and ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz would also facilitate the movement of several of Riḍā's disciples to the <a href="Hejaz">Ḥijāz</a> in the 1920s. Assisted by Ibn Saud, their efforts would also mark the shift from the exclusivist, narrow-minded prone to "<a href="Takfiri">Takfiri</a>sm"; to a new reformed Wahhabi tradition open to outside world. The revived Wahhabi movement was more tolerant and no longer hostile to the surrounding populations, unlike its earlier iterations.
Rida's endorsement of Wahhabism would be a decisive factor in the spread of its influences beyond the kingdom's borders. Wahhabi scholars would consistently emphasize their affinity to mainstream <a href="Sunni%20Islam">Sunni</a> <a href="Madhhab">legal schools</a> and affirm that their tradition was amongst the several manifestations of the Islamic reform movement of "<a href="Salafi%20movement">Salafiyya</a>". To further mainstreamise and refine Wahhabism; 'Abdul Aziz would also encourage the Saudi "ulema" to tone down their dogmatic views. Rida's disciples in <a href="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> would make significant efforts to reform Wahhabis towards "<a href="Salafi%20movement">Salafiyya</a>". One of the biggest efforts towards reintegration of Wahhabism into the mainstream Sunni World was through the establishment of "<a href="https%3A//ar.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/%25D9%2585%25D8%25AF%25D8%25B1%25D8%25B3%25D8%25A9_%25D8%25AF%25D8%25A7%25D8%25B1_%25D8%25A7%25D9%2584%25D8%25AA%25D9%2588%25D8%25AD%25D9%258A%25D8%25AF">Dar al-Tawhid</a>" ("The House of Unity"), a religious educational institute in <a href="Taif">Ta’if</a> headed by <a href="Muhammad%20Bahjat%20Athari">Muhammad Bahjat al Bitar</a>, a disciple of Rashid Rida. Another disciple <a href="https%3A//ar.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/%25D9%2585%25D8%25AD%25D9%2585%25D8%25AF_%25D8%25AD%25D8%25A7%25D9%2585%25D8%25AF_%25D8%25A7%25D9%2584%25D9%2581%25D9%2582%25D9%258A%23%3A~%3Atext%3D%25D9%2588%25D9%2584%25D8%25AF%2520%25D9%2585%25D8%25AD%25D9%2585%25D8%25AF%2520%25D8%25AD%25D8%25A7%25D9%2585%25D8%25AF%2520%25D8%25A7%25D9%2584%25D9%2581%25D9%2582%25D9%258A%2520%25D8%25A8%25D9%2582%25D8%25B1%25D9%258A%25D8%25A9%2C%25D9%2584%25D9%2585%2520%25D9%258A%25D9%2583%25D9%2585%25D9%2584%25D9%2587%2520%25D9%2584%25D8%25B8%25D8%25B1%25D9%2588%25D9%2581%2520%25D8%25A7%25D8%25B6%25D8%25B7%25D8%25B1%25D8%25AA%25D9%2587%2520%25D9%2584%25D8%25B0%25D9%2584%25D9%2583.">Muhammad Hamid al-Fiqi</a>, would be appointed as the president of the Meccan Department of Printing and Publication ("raʾīs shuʿbat al-ṭabʿ wa-l-nashr bi-Makka"). Based on the advise of Rida, Al-Fiqi would start a new Islamic journal "Al-Islah" in <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a>, modelled after "<a href="Al-Man%C4%81r%20%28magazine%29">Al-Manar</a>". "Al-Islah" championed the key doctrines of "Salafiyya" and integrated Arabia into the transnational network of Islamic reformist efforts while fostering a broader sense of Islamic identity amongst the <a href="Arabs">Arab</a> elite.
Aftermath.
The <a href="Establishment%20of%20Saudi%20Arabia">establishment of Saudi rule</a> over <a href="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> marked a landmark event in the history of the <a href="Arab%20world">Arab world</a> in particular and the <a href="Muslim%20world">Islamic world</a> in general. The alliance of Rida and the Wahhabi state laid the foundational coalitions of a fundamentalist <a href="Pan-Islamism">Pan-Islamist</a> movement, a new <a href="Sunni%20orthodoxy">Sunni orthodoxy</a>, with direct support from <a href="Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> since 1926. Inspired by the theological paradigm elaborated by Rashid Rida, his disciple <a href="Hassan%20al-Banna">Hasan al-Banna</a> founded the <a href="Muslim%20Brotherhood">Society of the Muslim Brothers</a> ("Jama'at al-Ikhwan al-Muslimeen") in 1928; which Rida himself was on the verge of joining shortly before his death. The Muslim Brotherhood would become the most influential movement of Pan-Islamism across the Arab world. The successful establishment of an <a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic state</a> in heartland of Islam significantly advanced the proliferation of the <a href="Islamic%20revival">Islamic revival</a>ist programme envisioned by Rashid Rida.
With the consolidation of <a href="Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi rule</a>, the <a href="Sufism">Sufi</a> institutions in <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a> were closed and replaced with Rashid Rida's Salafi comrades and the Najdi "<a href="Ulama">ulema</a>". Sufi influence was being curtailed and "Salafiyya" movement was being promoted on an international scale. In 1961, the <a href="Islamic%20University%20of%20Madinah">Islamic University of Medina</a> was founded and it would serve as an international seminary for propagation of Salafi "<a href="Dawah">Da'wa</a>" globally, with coordination of leading Salafis all over the world. Vast majority of its students came outside Saudi Arabia with wide-ranging scholarships. After graduation, these students would return to their native lands with prestige and would get appointed as imams, leaders, etc. or found "Da'wa" organisations of their own.
Death.
Rashid Rida died on his way back to Cairo from Suez, where he had gone to see off his patron, King of Saudi Arabia <a href="Abdulaziz%20Ibn%20Saud">Abdulaziz Ibn Saud</a>. Rida had committed most of his resources for Islamic reform through publishing and other revivalist efforts. Hence, he faced financial difficulties throughout his career and he died poor and in debt.
The Sheikh of <a href="Al-Azhar%20Mosque">Al Azhar</a>, <a href="Mustafa%20al-Maraghi">Mustafa al Maraghi</a>, remarked that Rida had three main opponents: Muslim modernists, non-Muslims, and religious obscurantists.

Egyptian hadith scholar and Rida's disciple, <a href="Ahmad%20Muhammad%20Shakir">Ahmad Shakir</a> wrote:"Islam has lost today a very high personality, an Imam, a Hujjah among the Imams of guidance, a great Mujahid and a great reformer. He lived benign and died a martyr!"
Views.
On Taqleed.
Rashid Rida was a leading exponent of <a href="Salafi%20movement">Salafism</a> and was especially critical of what he termed "blind following" ("<a href="Taqlid">Taqleed</a>") of excessive <a href="Sufism">Sufism</a>; which he believed to have distorted the original message of Islam. He distinguished between imitating a "madhab" and following Muhammad using the commendable term ""ittiba"" (following); which denoted following the Prophetic "<a href="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>" through textual proofs. He encouraged both laymen and scholars to read and study directly the primary sources of Islam by themselves. This principle also enabled Rida to address a number of contemporary subjects and challenges in a modern way, articulating his defense of Islam in a renovated language that sometimes led him to hold un-conventional views. Not only was "Taqlid" inherently blameworthy, Rida also condemned its resultant factionalism, writing:"What is harmful is fragmentation of Muslims into sects and parties, while each of them requires its members to follow a scholar whom they call an "<a href="imam">imam</a>", and they follow him in every word and opinion, and assemble themselves against the followers of another scholar, leading finally to the negligence of the Book ["<a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>"] and the "<a href="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>""
Condemning "<a href="Taqlid">Taqlid</a>" theologically, Rida argued that rigid adherence to the "<a href="Madhhab">mad'habs</a>" have divided the <a href="Ummah">Muslim "Ummah"</a> into sectarian factions; almost causing the jurists to worship the four Imams like deities, which contradicted "<a href="Tawhid">Tawhid</a>". Moreover, it blocked the independent thinking of Muslims and prohibited their right to access the Scriptures directly, which enabled the tyrants, supported by the corrupt "ʿulamaʾ", to justify oppression and preserve their despotism. He would also explain that the hadiths regarding the saved sect ("al-firqa al-nājiya") referred to the "Ahl al-Ittiba" (the people who followed proof-texts) who are the "saved ones" ("al-Najin"); while the "madhab" fanatics belonged to the innovated group. Despite this, Rida did not ignore the legacy of the four "mad'habs" and viewed its legal literature as a resource from which he derived rulings, adapting to changing circumstances. Although he placed the four "Imams" at the peak of juristic excellence, he claimed that <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya</a> was practically more relevant for contemporary Muslims.
Rida's criticism of "Taqlid" extended well beyond the confines of <a href="Sharia">Islamic law</a> and <a href="Schools%20of%20Islamic%20theology">theology</a> to include socio-political developments. He believed that socio-political associations and its consequent "<a href="Asabiyyah">Asabiyyah</a>" (partisanships) influenced "madhab" affiliations and fanaticism. He was far more critical of "Al-Mutafarnijun" (Europeanised emulators); whom he regarded as being guilty of "Taqlid" and abandoning the path of the "<a href="Salaf">Salaf</a>" (pious forefathers). While the "madhab" partisans are influenced by administrative positions of power and promote governmental interests; the "Mutafarnijun" create more damage by dividing the "Ummah" based on different languages, nationalities and countries and conceiving new identities within the nation-states. Labelling the Europeanisers who associated with new national identities as "<a href="Mulhid">Mulhid</a>" (heretics) and "<a href="Apostasy%20in%20Islam">Murtadd</a>" (apostates), Rida wrote:"Nationalist adherence…is the destruction of the foundation of their community. They think that through it they build a new foundation better than that which history built for them [i.e via Islam].. We have learned with great surprise and despair…that some Syrians and Egyptians who continue to despise themselves and prefer the Turks over their own people, choose to follow them (taqlīduhum) in this... they are like [the Turks] in their unbelief (kufr) and ‘negation [of divine attributes]’ (ta‘ṭīl) and the lack of feeling for religious connections"
Drawing on <a href="Hanbali">Hanbali</a> and <a href="Shafi%CA%BDi%20school">Shafi'i</a> legal traditions that supported the continuity of "<a href="Ijtihad">Ijtihad</a>", Rida also employed its doctrine into practice. Rida defined the application of "Ijtihad" strictly in terms of "pure adherence to the provisions of the "<a href="Quran">Qur’an</a>" and "<a href="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>" and upon the understanding of the "<a href="Salaf">Salaf al-Salih</a>"" and restricted its scope by enforcing the authority of "<a href="Ijma">'Ijma</a>" (scholarly consensus). Rida's position on the scope of "ijtihād" would pave a middle-ground between the <a href="Islamic%20modernism">Modernist</a> conceptualisation of "ijtihād" as an all-inclusive creative endeavour and the minimalist view of "ijtihād" which restricted it to a narrow legal spectrum of <a href="Madhhab">"mad'hab"</a> partisanship. <a href="South%20Asia">South Asia</a>n thinker <a href="Muhammad%20Iqbal">Muhammad Iqbal</a> (d. 1938) represented the former position, while the <a href="Deobandi">Deobandi movement</a> advocated the latter. During his life-time when "Taqlid" tradition was predominant, "<a href="fatwa">fatwa</a>s" were not issued by "Ijtihad". Beginning from 1903, Rida issued fatwas in "Al-Manar" answering questions sent by readers from all corners of the Islamic World and proclaimed the "fatwas" as his "Ijtihad" (independent legal reasoning). His exceptional claim to exercise of "Ijtihad" would impart a major influence on future <a href="Islamic%20revivalism">Islamic revivalist</a> movements.
On Islamic Revival.
Rida believed that the early Muslims' upholding of "<a href="Tawhid">Tawheed</a>"(Oneness of God), and "<a href="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>" were the primary reason for their spiritual and material success. They were motivated by the "Qur'anic" teachings which taught them to be independent, free from blind imitation("<a href="Taqlid">taqleed</a>") and prepared them to spiritually and materially lead mankind. Thus they were able to establish a mighty civilisation unrivalled across the world with highly advanced science and technology and spread civilisation across all the lands they conquered, freeing its inhabitants from oppression and "<a href="Jahiliyya">Jahiliyya</a>"(darkness). Rida believed that the Muslim decline started after the end of the <a href="Abbasid%20Caliphate">Islamic Caliphates</a> in the 13th century, when the Arab rule ceased and power shifted to the non-Arabs who abandoned the "<a href="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>" and innovated various superstitions that contradicted the Scriptures. Based on his reading of "<a href="hadith">hadith</a>", Rida believed that after this decline, a second Islamic victory is prophesied. He undertook initiatives for a global <a href="Islamic%20revival">Islamic Renaissance</a> in that path.
Rida believed that the <a href="Muslim%20world">Muslim World</a> faced acute crises in spiritual, educational and legislative affairs. He identified Islamic religious reform "as a triple unification of doctrine, law, and ethics." Rida's adoption of "<a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabiyyah's</a>" puritanical tenets after 1918 symbolised his adoption of a <a href="Hanbali">Hanbali</a>te reformist framework, to carry out his revivalist efforts. While strictly adhering to "<a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>" and "Hadith", the Hanbali school called for the application of Ijtihad where the Scriptures are vague. It also accepted the general Islamic principle of "<a href="Maslaha">Maslaha</a>"(public interest). Inorder to expound a comprehensive Islamic system of law, government, education, and ethics in the modern world; Rida revived the classical Islamic theory of life. The reconstitution of the Islamic system was only possible by directly returning to the original sources. In this, he also defended the superiority of "naql" (textual sources) over "<a href="%27Aql">'aql</a>" (rational sources) and condemned <a href="Islamic%20philosophy">philosophy</a> and "<a href="Sufism">tasawwuf</a>".
Rashid Rida travelled to <a href="Europe">Europe</a> only once, for a specific political purpose, and was ignorant of <a href="Languages%20of%20Europe">European languages</a>. He disliked the social life of Europeans and was hostile to <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a>. Despite this, he had a robust sensitivity to challenges faced by Muslims in the modern world. He believed that the <a href="Islamic%20Golden%20Age%23Decline">inner decay of Muslims</a> as well as the efforts of <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic Church</a>, prevented <a href="Ethnic%20groups%20in%20Europe">Europeans</a> from embracing <a href="Islam">Islam</a>. He wanted Muslims to accept aspects of <a href="modernity">modernity</a> only to the extent to which it was essential for the recovery of Islamic strength. By referring to the juristic principles of necessity, he considered it as a duty for Muslims to study modern sciences and technology. Rida repeatedly urged the legal experts and the "<a href="Ulama">Ulema</a>" of his era to come together and produce legal works based directly from "Quran" and "hadith", easy for all <a href="Mumin">believers</a> to comprehend and in accordance with the needs of the age.
On Secularism and Modernism.
Rashid Rida believed that the management of state affairs and its principles were an integral part of <a href="Islamic%20faith">Islamic faith</a>. Accordingly, he called for the restoration of <a href="Worldwide%20caliphate">Islamic Caliphate</a> and waged fierce battles against <a href="Secularism">secularist</a> trends that emerged across the <a href="Arab%20world">Arab World</a> during the early twentieth century. He denounced calls for separation of religion and state, advocated by some of the former students of Muhammad 'Abduh, as the most dangerous threat to Islam. By the 1920s, Rida had discovered that his most formidable opponents were not the tradition-bound Sufi-Ash'arite "ulama" of Al-Azhar but the Western-educated secularists who pushed Abduh's utilitarian principles far beyond. Rida made vehement denunciations and attacks against modernists such as <a href="Ali%20Abdel%20Raziq">Ali Abdel Raziq</a> and Ahmed Safwat. By this point, Rida's main priority had shifted to repeal what he considered "Western invasion of Islamic culture". This shift was also evident in his promotion of the <a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabi</a> cause and active promotion of "<a href="Salafi%20movement">Salafiyya</a>", championing the works of <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya</a>, <a href="Ibn%20Qayyim%20al-Jawziyya">Ibn Qayyim</a>, <a href="Ibn%20Qudamah">Ibn Qudama</a>, etc.
Rida called upon <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a> to shun the imitation of foreigners and their ways, and labelled the <a href="Islamic%20modernism">Islamic modernists</a> as “false renewers” and “heretics" whose efforts were harming Muslim societies. He would also severely arraign the scholars who provided "<a href="fatwa">fatwa</a>s" (religious rulings) that aligned with the ideals of modernists. Rida asserted that a society which properly obeyed "<a href="Sharia">Sharia</a>" would be able to successfully resist both <a href="capitalism">capitalism</a> as well as the disorder of class-based <a href="socialism">socialism</a>; since such a society would be unsusceptible to its temptations. The <a href="Westernization">Westernising</a> turn of Abduh's modernist disciples, was defied by Rida. He would propel towards the nascent <a href="Wahhabism">Wahhabi</a> state of <a href="Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> and its "<a href="Ulama">Ulema</a>". Rida despised the Westernising and <a href="Secularization">secularising</a> trends in Muslim societies and viewed them as the direct outcome of the modernist movement. Dismissing the modernist advocacy of cultural synthesis, he emphasized the self-sufficiency and comprehensiveness of Islamic faith, and adopted a hostile attitude towards Western powers; socially and politically. Rida's polemical posture against the modernists and themes of Islamic self-sufficiency, <a href="Anti-Western%20sentiment">anti-Westernism</a>, etc. would portend the emergence of transnational <a href="Islamism">Islamist</a> movements such as the <a href="Muslim%20Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a> and "<a href="Jamaat-e-Islami">Jamaat-i Islami</a>".
In his treatise "Yusr al-Islam wa Usül at-Tashri' al-'Ämm" (“The Accommodating Spirit of Islam and the Sources of General Jurisprudence”), Rida explains that he favors a "middle path" between the rigid conservatives whose legal interpretations are all tied to one traditional sect or another, and those secularists who at most use Islamic “symbols” but are ready in practice to disregard Islam entirely and to borrow legal codes from Europe or evolve new ones on the basis of local convenience:
"The moderate advocates of Islamic reform are those who affirm that it is possible to resuscitate Islam and renew its true guidance by following the Qur’än and the true Sunna and the guidance of the Virtuous Forefathers ["as-salaf as-Salih"], and by seeking the help of the learning of the <a href="Imam">"Imams"</a>, without cleaving to particular sectarian books and teachings around which the first group has solidified. They also affirm that it is possible to combine this with the noblest forms of civilization and organization which the second groups calls for. Indeed, they believe that religion and the most modern techniques of civilization and power, on both of which they advocate primary reliance, are two friends in agreement, not in conflict, and that each adds to the power and nobility of the other."
On Zionism.
The Zionist programme to create a <a href="Jewish%20state">Jewish state</a> in Palestine was a source of concern throughout the Islamic World, during the early 20th century. Muhammad Rashid Rida was one of the earliest critics of <a href="Zionism">Zionism</a> and wrote an article condemning the movement as early as 1898. Rida had warned early on that <a href="Jews">Jews</a> were being mobilised by Zionists to migrate to <a href="Palestine%20%28region%29">Palestine</a> with <a href="European%20colonial%20powers">European</a> approval. Rida urged the Arabs to wake up and take action against the Zionists. Quoting leaders of Zionist movement themselves, Rida warned that the goal of the movement was to establish a Zionist state in Palestine. Rida also directed critique against Jews in general. In his 1929 article “"Thawrat Filistin"”, Rida propagated <a href="Antisemitism">anti-semitic</a> stereotypes. Rida claimed that Jews were a "selfish and chauvinist, cunning and perfidious" people who sought to exploit and exterminate other people. He alleged that Jews plotted in Europe to undermine the power of <a href="Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>, introduced <a href="freemasonry">freemasonry</a> and through it; manipulated the <a href="Bolsheviks">Bolsheviks</a> and the <a href="Young%20Turks">Young Turks</a> against the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian</a> and <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> empires. Rida believed that capitalism was created by the Jews as a tool to "enslave the whole world through their money".
Rida regarded the Zionist enterprise as part of the wider <a href="British%20Empire">British imperial</a> <a href="Divide%20and%20rule">scheme</a> to consolidate their regional domination and provoke "<a href="Fitna%20%28word%29">Fitna</a>" (civil strife) amongst <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a>. In his 1929 <a href="Antisemitism">anti-semitic</a> treatise "Thawrat Filastin" ( Revolution in Palestine); Rida identified Jews as historically the most fanatical people in "<a href="Asabiyyah">Asabiyya</a>" (in-group solidarity); who refused to assimilate with other cultures. He listed a number of historical crimes of the <a href="Israelites">Israelites</a> such as their offenses against the <a href="Prophets%20and%20messengers%20in%20Islam">Prophets of God</a>, their lapsing into "<a href="Shirk%20%28Islam%29">shirk</a>" (polytheism) and "<a href="riba">riba</a>" (usury). So God punished them, taking away their <a href="Hasmonean%20dynasty">kingdom</a> and subjecting them to centuries of <a href="Persecution%20of%20Jews%23Western%20and%20Christian%20antisemitism">Christian persecution</a>. Rida asserted that the Jews had gained immense influence in capitalist countries through their control of the Western banking system, and thus have succeeded in turning the Christian states against Muslims. The Jews are seeking the resurrection of their <a href="Greater%20Israel">religious state</a> in <a href="Palestine%20%28region%29">Palestine</a> to pave the way for the arrival of their long-awaited <a href="Messiah%20in%20Judaism">Messiah</a>, who in fact is the <a href="Al-Masih%20ad-Dajjal">Anti-Christ</a>; who will be killed by the true <a href="Messiah%20in%20Islam">Messiah</a>, <a href="Jesus%20in%20Islam">Jesus</a> (‘Īsa bin Mariam) as per the Islamic Prophesies of the <a href="Jesus%20in%20Islam%23Second%20coming">Second Coming of Jesus</a>. Impatient with their endless wait, free-thinkers skeptical of religious eschatology had founded the Zionist movement. Since the Jews were only competent in financial sector, but not in military affairs; Rida argued; the Zionists were backed by the military might of British.
In 1933, Rida issued a "<a href="fatwa">fatwa</a>" forbidding all Muslims to sell land to Jews in Palestine, ruling that such sales represented the "betrayal of <a href="Islam">Islam</a>" and complicity with Zionism. In response to a query from an Arab living in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> under the new <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi</a> regime, Rida propounded that the <a href="Germanic%20peoples">Germanic people</a> had begun taking their vengeance upon the Jews; for their roles in undermining Germany during the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>. Although Rida's theology was ideologically at odds with Nazi doctrines, he nevertheless viewed them as sweeping away heresies and false beliefs, clearing the path for the ultimate triumph of the Islamic faith. He viewed <a href="Kemalism">Kemalism</a> and <a href="Communism">Communism</a> as the immediate enemies of Islam, both of which were directly threatening Muslim territories.
Four months before his death, Rida paid a ringing tribute for his disciple <a href="Grand%20Mufti%20of%20Jerusalem">Grand Mufti</a> <a href="Amin%20al-Husseini">Hajji Amin al-Husayni</a>; praising him as a brilliant <a href="Pan-Islamism">Pan-Islamic</a> "<a href="Mujahideen">Mujahid</a>" leader of <a href="Palestinians">Palestinians</a>, and extolled his skillful efforts. In one of his final texts published in 1935, Rida called upon all Muslims to unite urgently and focus all their resources to defeat the Jews. In Rida's view:"‘If we want to save our homeland and "<a href="Ummah">umma</a>" from Jewish domination by means of the moral power of religion, we shall have to take the path traced by our ancestors ["<a href="salaf">salaf</a>ina"], who defeated the Jews in the first epoch [of Islam] and expelled them from the <a href="Arabian%20Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a>."
On Christianity.
Rida was highly sensitive to the openly hostile and <a href="Islamophobia">Islamophobic</a> attitudes prevalent amongst <a href="Orientalism">Orientalists</a> and European <a href="Christians">Christians</a> of his era. Before promoting the vision of a <a href="Caliphate">Caliphate</a> as a means of Islamic revival, Rida was trying to counteract the activities of <a href="Christian%20mission">Christian mission</a>aries for founding a society to for organised <a href="Dawah">Islamic "Da'wa"</a> outside Ottoman territories. He was also concerned by what he regarded as sympathies of native <a href="Arab%20Christians">Arab Christians</a> to <a href="colonial%20powers">colonial powers</a>. When he organised his <a href="Caliphate">Caliphate</a> theory, his vision would have recognised both <a href="Judaism">Judaism</a> and Christianity, granting non-Muslims the right to serve in administration and judicial system.(except the Islamic "<a href="Sharia">shar'i</a>" courts)
In Rida's view, the only ‘true’ mission of solid faith in Christian history was that of the disciples of <a href="Jesus">Jesus</a>; and any later missionary attempt was false. Riḍā perceived the Christian missions as an integral part of the colonial presence in the <a href="Muslim%20world">Muslim world</a> and was convinced that Europe made use of religion as a political instrument for mobilising European Christians by inflaming their ‘fanatic’ feelings against other nations. In spite of this, Rida did promote efforts to reconcile between Muslims and Christians.
However, Rida accused <a href="Eastern%20Christianity">Oriental Christians</a> in general of being the tools of colonial powers and of conspiring with "atheist Westerners" against Islam. In a series of articles published in 1911 compiled under the title "al-Muslimun wa-l-qutb" ("The Muslims and the Copts"), Rida condemned Muslims for dividing over nationalism. In his view, <a href="Egyptian%20nationalism">nationalist</a> slogans were exploited by the colonial powers and would only favor the Coptic minority. He mocked the <a href="Copts">Copts</a>’ claim to be descended from the “heathen, God-hating” Pharaohs and their demand to positions of power, responding that "they lack experience". Rida also applauded the 1911 Muslim congress organised as a response to Congress of Asyut in 1911 that demanded Coptic minority rights. Rida believed that the <a href="Western%20culture">Western Civilisation</a> could not be considered "Christian" but only materialistic, and predicted that its vices would lead to its self-destruction. He alleged that the West sought to turn Muslims away from their religion, either by degrading their moral values, or converting them to Christianity, or both.
On Shi'ism.
From being a person who was accommodative towards <a href="Shia%20Islam">Shiism</a>, Rashid Rida would gradually become a sharp critique of it. In a book originally published in 1929, he states that he was once willing to work with the balanced reformers amongst Shias, but explains that the situation has changed. He also alleged that Shiites "worship the dead" attributing to their intercessionary practices towards "<a href="Wali">awliyaa</a>" in their shrines and called upon Shias to condemn these practices. Although he fell short of censuring all Shias, Rida left them few options. Pan-Islamic unity was still conceivable, but it had to be on Salafi terms. In 1927, in the context of heightened communal tensions following the Saudi's heavy-handed efforts on the Shi'i population of the kingdom, "al-Manar" published a series of seven anti-Shi'i articles written by the Salafi scholar and Rida's disciple <a href="Muhammad%20Taqi-ud-Din%20al-Hilali">Muhammad Taqi ud din al-Hilali</a>. Rida condemned the Shia for "supporting the Tatar and Crusader invasions" and alleged that <a href="Rafida">"Raafidi"</a> doctrines were formulated by a Jewish-Zoroastrian conspiracy aimed at "perverting Islam and weakening the Arabs". Rida called upon "moderate Shi'is" to dissociate themselves from the stagnant Shia clergy and condemn intercessionary practices such as beseeching their religious figures from the "<a href="Ahl%20al-Bayt">Ahl al-Bayt</a>" and "<a href="Awliyaa">Awliyaa</a>" (saints) in their graves; which he equated with "<a href="Shirk%20%28Islam%29">shirk</a>" (polytheism). Only then shall they be incorporated into his <a href="pan-Islamic">pan-Islamic</a> ecumenical paradigm.
Despite all this, Rida was the most important modern Sunni scholar that influenced modern Shiite <a href="exegesis">exegesis</a>. Rida's prolific Quranic commentary ("<a href="Tafsir">Tafseer</a>") is regarded by both Sunni and Shiite scholars as groundbreaking in the field of "Tafseer". As traditional Shiism came into contact with various Islamic reform movements, such as the "salafiyya" which emphasised the importance of adhering to ""<a href="Qur%27an">Qur'an</a>" and "<a href="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>"" over personalities, its orthodox reluctance to engage in "Qur'anic" exegesis was highly challenged in the modern World. Rida's "Tafseer" and his innovative approach were important in inducing a similar tendency within Shiism.
Darwinism.
Although Rashid Rida personally rejected <a href="Darwinism">Darwin's theory of evolution</a>, he did not outright denounce someone who expounded the theory as an <a href="Kafir">unbeliever</a>. <a href="Muhammad%20Abduh">Abduh</a> had interpreted certain aspects of the story of <a href="Adam%20in%20Islam">Adam</a> such as "questions of <a href="Angels%20in%20Islam">angels</a>", "prostration of angels", "tree", etc. in an allegorical manner. Commenting on his teacher's explanation, Rashid Rida said that what was done by "<a href="Ustad">al-Ustadh</a>" (teacher), is no more as <a href="al-Ghazali">al-Ghazali</a>. Rida points out that Abduh did not interpret <a href="Adam%20in%20Islam">Adam</a> as a mere myth. Defending Abduh, Rida argued that Darwinism cannot answer whether humans originate from a single lineage or not. Hence, Rida argues that the <a href="Islamic%20views%20on%20evolution%23Creation%20of%20humanity">Islamic creationist</a> belief of Adam being the first man doesn't contradict Darwinism.
However, Rida sharply distanced himself from the figurative interpretation of "<a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>" favoured by Abduh and <a href="Jamal%20al-Din%20al-Afghani">Afghani</a>. According to Rida, anybody who denied the historical existence of Adam and <a href="Abraham%20in%20Islam">Abraham</a> is guilty of <a href="apostasy">apostasy</a>. Like the medieval theologian <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya</a>, Rida held that there's no possibility of reason or science contradicting any "<a href="Quran">Qur’anic</a>" text.
On "Istishan" (juristic discretion), "Istislah" and "Maslaha" (public interest).
Throughout his legal writings, Rida tried to demonstrate that "<a href="Sharia">Sharia</a>" was intended and suited to be a comprehensive legal structure for the Islamic society. In an early series of articles in "<a href="Al-Man%C4%81r%20%28magazine%29">Al-Manar</a>" titled “Debates Between the Reformer and the Slavish Imitator” ("Muhäwarät al-Muslih wal-Muqallid"), Rida takes the view that the fixed "shar'i" principles in the <a href="Muamalat">"mu'ämalät"</a> (social transactions) are of only a general character, allowing for considerable adaptation by successive generations of <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a> in the light of the demands of their worldly welfare, while it is only the '<a href="Ibadah">"ibädät"</a> (governing matters of ritual and worship) that do not admit of interpretive change. According to Rashid Rida, the <a href="Hanafi">Hanafi</a> principle of "<a href="Istihsan">Istihsan</a>" (ruling in which a benefit to the Community is confirmed) is essentially an application of this spirit. However, Rida divided "<a href="Muamalat">Mu'amalat</a>" into two categories: i) moral issues and ii) morally irrelevant issues. The former are similar to "'Ibadat" rules which were Revealed by God who defined moral norms and hence, fixed. Those who break these rules are sinful <a href="Fasiq">transgressors</a>. The latter category of issues, can be solved through the process of "<a href="Qiyas">Qiyas</a>" (analogical reasoning). Thus, like "Istihsan", "Qiyas" is a fundamental principle necessary for the relevant application of the law.
For medieval jurists such as <a href="Shihab%20al-Din%20al-Qarafi">Al-Qarafi</a>, <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya</a> etc., "<a href="istislah">istislah</a>" was but a logical extension of "<a href="qiyas">qiyas</a>", whereby a consideration of utility neither explicitly enjoined nor excluded by the revealed texts would be assumed as a valid basis for judgment. Rashid Rida adopted this rationale, acknowledging that the conclusions of "istisläh" were accordingly not legally binding as a firmly grounded "qiyas" (as opposed to a "qiyas" without precise textual basis), for "no individual is entitled to require or forbid others to perform an act without Divine authorization".
However, in matters of public policy this doesn't prevent the government from enacting ordinances based on utility, provided that the government rests on the proper foundations of ""<a href="shura">shura</a>"" (consultation) amongst "ulul amr" (qualified authorities) and that such ordinances do not conflict with clear Divine Revelation. Citing the <a href="Al-Andalus">Andalusian</a> "<a href="Faq%C4%ABh">Faqih</a>" <a href="Al-Shatibi">Ash-Shatibi</a> (d.790 H), Rida suggests that much of the legal rulings built through the meticulous process of "<a href="Qiyas">Qiyas</a>", can actually be reached by an equally valid (yet much simpler) process of "istislah". Citing <a href="Shihab%20al-Din%20al-Qarafi">Al-Qarafi</a>, Rida states that many "<a href="Ulama">ulema</a>" feared that tyrants would use ""maslaha" as an excuse for following their desires and imposing absolutism upon their population. Rida concludes that the solution should be to reform the political system so that decisions of public policy and law rests on the hands of qualified persons - "<a href="Ahl%20al-hall%20wal-aqd">ahl al-hall wal-'aqd</a>" or "ulul amr"" - through mutual consultation ("shura") and ruler responsible to them. If this is done, "there will be no reason to fear that "Masalih" will be a means for corruption", Rida says, thus lifting the restrictions on deduction of legal ordinances.
However, Rida was clear in specifying that general principles cannot supersede clear-cut texts. He stated that a soundly transmitted Scriptural text can only be superseded by a specific text which is more superior. It could also be superseded by general texts of "<a href="Quran">Qurʾan</a>" and authentic "<a href="hadith">hadith</a>s" that permit believers to prevent damage to themselves or to commit prohibited actions in a state of emergencies; such as endangerment of life. Rida asserted that such a permission is valid only during the situation of extreme necessity; and that the degree of allowance was proportional to the scope of necessity. Maintaining that Revealed texts are superior to "<a href="Maslaha">Maslaha</a>"; Rida's legal approach towards the revealed texts and "maṣlaḥa" was based on the criterion and mechanisms elaborated by classical jurists such as Al-Shatibi and <a href="Najm%20ad-Din%20al-Tufi">Al-Tufi</a>. In addition, Rida's legal doctrine continued the juristic traditions of a number of prominent "<a href="Faq%C4%ABh">Fuqaha</a>" between the 10th and 14th centuries such as <a href="Al-Ghazali">Al-Ghazali</a>, <a href="Fakhr%20al-Din%20al-Razi">Fakhr al-Din al-Razi</a>, al-Qarafi, <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya</a>, etc. During these four centuries, Islamic jurists had commonly employed "maṣlaḥa" as an amenity for legal resolution and juristic dynamism. As Rida saw it, the classical jurists had sufficiently elaborated the “philosophical, moral and hermeneutical controls" for valid utilisation of the principles of "Maslaha" (public interest). Thus, he engaged with the traditional theoretical literature of classical <a href="Sunni%20Islam">Sunni</a> "<a href="Fiqh">Fiqh</a>" and conveyed its rich heritage to his readers in a sophisticated manner. Rida would also credit Al-Ghazali and Al-Shatibi for his revivalism of "maṣlaḥa"; which revamped the principle within the traditional legal framework of "<a href="Qiyas">Qiyas</a>" (analogical reasoning).
Rida's doctrines would later be extended by <a href="Islamic%20modernism">modernists</a> to uphold "maslaha" as an independent legal source, making "qiyas" dispensable and formulating positive laws directly on <a href="Utilitarianism">utilitarian</a> grounds, for the "wisdom behind the Revealed Laws is no longer inscrutable", thus creating new implications. Throughout the 1920s, when such conclusions were drawn by the modernists based on these premises, Rida would object strenuously. He vehemently denounced the Egyptian lawyer Ahmed Safwat for promotion of "non-adherence to the texts" of "<a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>" and "<a href="Sunni%20Islam">Sunna</a>" in particular matters in the name of public utility. Although Rida stated that "<a href="Mujahideen">Mujtahids</a>" are obliged to take a broad view of all considerations affecting the public interest, "textual limits" had to be respected. The general public was obliged to follow the qualified "<a href="Mujahideen">Mujtahids</a>" unquestionably on "mu'amalat" (wordly Transactions) and their consensus was a legal source ("hujja shar'iyya").
On Women.
Rashid Rida believed that <a href="Islam">Islam</a> treats women and men equally in terms of their spiritual obligations and their ability to earn <a href="God%20in%20Islam">God's</a> favor. He holistically addressed gender issues such as sexual freedom, women's exploitation in the workplace, and the rising cases of illegitimate children which were creating serious problems in European societies. He contrasted this with <a href="Gender%20roles%20in%20Islam">Islamic gender roles</a>, which defined a woman's position in both household and society; and maintained that it represented the proper solution to the social problems faced by the most advanced societies. While men are heads of the household, Islam granted women the right to choose a spouse and gave them clearly stipulated rights and responsibilities in a marriage. He also stipulated that consent of <a href="Wali%20%28Islamic%20legal%20guardian%29">male guardian</a> of women was essential for a "<a href="Marriage%20in%20Islam">Nikah</a>" (marriage) to be valid, since it stabilises the domestic order and befits the honor of both women and men. He criticised those followers of "<a href="Hanafi">Hanafi</a>" school, who didn't adhere to this stipulation and confuted his position, as bigoted partisans to "madhabs" guilty of abandoning the "<a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>" and "<a href="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>" in favour of their law schools.
Rida was also a firm defender of traditional Islamic views on <a href="Polygyny%20in%20Islam">polygamy</a>, presenting it as a solution to the emerging social ills afflicting societies; such as free mixing of men and women in workplaces and consequent sexual freedoms. In one of his last treatises "A Call to the Fair Sex" published in 1932, a treatise addressed to the <a href="Women%20in%20Islam">Muslim women</a>, Rida argued that polygamy not only solved the problems associated with promiscuity and its resultant evils, but also addressed the difficulties produced by the loss of numerous men in wars. The book condemned the calls for equality between men and women in the workplace and in politics; and warned about the folly of imitating Western women in their misguided ways. Rida declared that calls for "the <a href="Feminist%20movement">liberation of women</a>" and other social reforms by the <a href="Islamic%20modernism">modernisers</a> were destroying the very fabric of Islamic societies. Rida also explained the etiquettes of <a href="Hijab">veiling</a>, emphasizing modesty for Muslim women, and addressed legal issues such as <a href="Divorce%20in%20Islam">divorce</a>. Although Rida hindered Muslim women from political participation, he encouraged association-based female Islamic activism; that called upon the government to outlaw free-mixing, wine-drinking, fronts of prostitution and demanded expansion of Islamic education for both males and females. In marital affairs, he held the view that wives are not obliged to cook, clean or take care of their children in "<a href="Sharia">Sharia</a>" and decried the hypocrisy of men who demanded more from their wives.
While Rida encouraged <a href="Women%20in%20Islam">Muslim women</a> to participate in the social life of Islam as they did during the early Islamic eras, he would stress that men are more capable and superior in terms of strength, intelligence, learning, physical labour, etc. Hence, they have "<a href="Wali%20%28Islamic%20legal%20guardian%29">Wilayah</a>" (legal guardianship) over women; but similar to the ruler over his subjects, the male authority should be exercised through "<a href="shura">shura</a>" (consultation). In this, Muslim men should follow Muhammad, who set forth the perfect example of the kind treatment of wives. Rida also defended <a href="Islamic%20views%20on%20slavery%23Traditional%20Islamic%20jurisprudence">Islamic slavery</a>, asserting that it protects women from harm and gives all of them a chance to bear children, and therefore, not in conflict with justice. According to Rida, the basic principle of "<a href="Sharia">Sharia</a>" concerning women, is that:"... every woman should have a legal guardian, to give her all she needs to be an honourable virgin, a virtuous wife, a careful mother, and a respected grandmother. She who is prevented from being wife or mother is not thereby prevented from enjoying protection and honour."
Definition of "Ahl al-Kitab".
Rashid Rida belonged to a minority of <a href="Sunni%20Islam">Sunni</a> scholars like <a href="Ahmad%20Sirhindi">"Mujaddid Alif Thani" Ahmad Sirhindi</a> who widened the definition of "<a href="People%20of%20the%20Book">Ahl al-Kitab</a>" to include <a href="Zoroastrianism">Magians</a>, <a href="Sabians">Sabians</a>, <a href="Buddhism">Buddhists</a>, <a href="Brahmin">Brahmin</a>s, <a href="Confucianism">Confucianists</a> and <a href="Shinto">Shinto</a>ists; since they held that they too were recipients of previous abrogated Revelations that upheld "<a href="Tawhid">Tawhid</a>". In their opinion, since those religious sects believed in God, Prophets, Revelation, Day of Judgment, Paradise and Hell, they are similar to the <a href="Jews">Jews</a> and <a href="Christians">Christians</a> and fall under the "Ahl al-Kitab" category; despite not being mentioned in "<a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>". Rida posited that "Qur'an" confined to mention those groups such as Jews, Christians, Sabi'is and Magians since they were known by the Arabs, to whom the Holy Qur'an was Revealed. He adopted this view from his discernment of the hadith "treat them in the same way as "Ahl al-Kitab"" regarding the Magians. Hence, Muslim men were permitted to engage in marital relations with women of these religions. Justifying this stance, Rida argued that marriages with non-Muslim women had been the manner of expanding the reach of Islam. However, Rida was clear in specifying that a Muslim woman was not allowed to marry a non-Muslim.
On "Riba" (Usury).
Rida considered that certain types of "<a href="riba">riba</a>" (usury) may be permitted in certain cases (i.e. in cases of extreme poverty or larger public interest). The medieval scholar Ibn al-Qayyim had distinguished between two types of "riba", "riba al-nasi'ah" and "riba al-fadl". <a href="Ibn%20Qayyim%20al-Jawziyya">Ibn Qayyim</a> maintained that "rib al-nasi'ah" was prohibited by Qur'an and <a href="Sunnah">Sunnah</a> definitively while the latter was only prohibited in order to stop the charging of interest. According to Ibn Qayyim, the prohibition of "riba al-fadl" was less severe and it could be allowed in dire need or greater public interest ("<a href="maslaha">maslaha</a>"). Ibn Qayyim considered that things prohibited in order to prevent access to evil become permissible when they result in a greater benefit. Hence under a compelling need, an item may be sold with delay in return for dirhams or for another weighed substance despite implicating "riba al-nasi'ah". In addition, Ibn Qayyim held that the sales of gold and silver jewelry for more than their equivalent weight in gold or silver was permissible, in consideration of workmanship and people's dire need. Although Ibn Qayyim clearly sought to restrict the scope of "riba’"s prohibition, he never stated that charging interest on loans was legal. In fact, Ibn Qayyim, relying on his reasoning, rejected the argument that coins (at the time made of gold and silver) could be sold for an excess in compensation for the minting process. In his opinion, although the authority gets them minted on wage payments, gold and silver should be used as a means of exchange, not trading with coins. Rida was influenced by both 'Abduh and Ibn Qayyims' legal reasonings.
As <a href="Grand%20Mufti%20of%20Egypt">Grand Mufti of Egypt</a>, 'Abduh had issued a fatwa in 1904 permitting to accept interest on deposits with the savings fund of the Egyptian post office. However, Rida was uneasy about 'Abduh's expansion of circumstances in which interest payment was permitted and chipped away at what 'Abduh had allowed.
