Rida glossed away 'Abduh's fatwa by suggesting that "Abduh only sanctioned returns on money deposited in this way on the understanding that the funds would be used for small investments by the post office in which the rules of transction would be strictly observed." He later would also highlight the public about "Abduh's fierce condemnation of the interest charged by the Egyptian banks." Most remarkably, Rida asserted that, as a direct violation of Divine command, "riba" rendered <a href="capitalism">capitalism</a> fundamentally at odds with an Islamic system.
Rashid Rida's stance on Riba is expressed in his treatise "Al-Riba w al-Mu`amalat fi al-Islam" (Riba and Transactions in Islam). In the treatise, Rida responds to a series of four "<a href="fatwa">fatwa</a>s" issued by <a href="Hyderabad">Hyderabad</a>i <a href="Hanafi">Hanafi</a> <a href="Faq%C4%ABh">jurists</a>. In their first fatwa, Hyderabadi jurists stated that concept of "riba" is abstract and quoted consensus over it. Responding to the fatwa, Rida defeated the claim of consensus while accepting it as a valid Hanafi stance. In the second fatwa, the Hyderabadi jurists defined "riba" as "an increase without compensation in sales" referring Hanafi legal treatises. Rida responded stating "This view isn't necessarily accepted, since his proof is not necessarily accepted", maintaining that "riba" isn't restricted to sales. The third fatwa stated that the benefit stipulated as condition in a loan is not the ""riba" explicitly mentioned in the Canonical Texts", since there is no explicit proof in "Qur'an and valid Hadith". Responding, Rida stated "If he means that it is not explicitly mentioned in the <a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>, we accept the statement, since the "riba" mentioned in Qur'an is restricted to "riba al-nasi'ah" applied to deferment of existing debts, rather than at the inception of the first contract". The fourth fatwa stated that a benefit arising as part of a loan is not "riba" by "<a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>" or valid "Hadith", but only on "<a href="Qiyas">Qiyas</a>" (analogical reasoning). The analogy is doubtful owing to "instigating factors" and even if the analogy was valid, it would be speculative since, "rulings based on analogy change with time". In his response, Rida acknowledged the validity of the position stating that "if the analogy was valid at an earlier time, its ruling may be reversed based on necessities of needs in current times".
In summary, Rashid Rida ruled that only the first increase in a termed loan is permissible in "<a href="Sharia">Sharia</a>", classifying it as "Riba al-Fadl". Based on his analysis of the reports in <a href="Tafsir%20al-Tabari">Tafsir al Tabari</a> that described the practice of "riba" during the pre-Islamic period, Rida distinguished the former from the usury practised during the <a href="Pre-Islamic%20Arabia">pre-Islamic period</a> ("Ribā Âl-Jāhilīyyá"). However, any further increase in returns or postponement of maturity date is unlawful. Differentiating between "Riba al-Jahiliyya" and other forms of Riba in his treatise "Al-Ríba Fi Al-Mūamālat Fíl Islām" ("Riba and Transactions in Islam"), Rida writes:"...[N]one of the authentic <a href="hadith">hadith</a> attributed to the <a href="Muhammad%20in%20Islam">Prophet</a> in relation to "riba" appears to mention the terms, 'loan' (qard) or 'debt' (dayn). This absence of any reference to loans or debts in riba-related hadith led a minority of jurists to contend that what is actually prohibited as "riba" is certain form of sales, which are referred to in the hadith literature."
Fatwa on Qur'an Translations.
The debut of Turkish translations of Qur'an in the newly established <a href="Turkey">Turkish Republic</a> with state involvement would ignite considerable controversy throughout the Muslim world in 1924. Muhammad Rashid Rida, who was highly influential in shaping opinion in the Muslim world, portrayed the state-sponsored project as a long-term plot to displace the Arabic Qur'an. Rida was correct in his suspicions that Mustafa Kemal's regime sought to tamper with Islamic rituals and accused the Turkish government of promoting heretical ideas in order "to turn the devout people among them away from the word of God the Exalted, who revealed it to the Arabian Prophet Muhammad in the clear Arabic tongue".
In response to a query by Sheikh Ahsan Shah Effendi Ahmad (in Russia), Rida issued a "<a href="fatwa">fatwa</a>" prohibiting Qur'anic translations. Rida listed numerous negative objections such as 1) literal translation of Qur'an identical to original text being impossible 2) this trend will sever "Islamic ties of unity" by stoking racial divisions 3) translation of Qur'an doesn't have the same quality of Qur'an, as the meaning will be "limited" by the translator's understanding. However Rida was clear in the fatwa that prohibition was on translation of Arabic Qur'an to substitute it with a non-Arabic one. Rida's criticism was not against the general idea of Qur'anic translations (which are considered interpretations of the scripture of <a href="Islam">Islam</a> in languages other than <a href="Classical%20Arabic">Arabic</a>). He was against the possibility that Muslim nations would have a substitute to the original text, which in his opinion was heresy and lead to disunity among Muslim nations.
Fatwa on statues.
The emerging controversy over erecting <a href="statue">statue</a>s in the early 20th-century Arab world was extensively addressed in the treatises of Rashid Rida. Rashid Rida believed that statues were forbidden in Islam, since they belonged to pagan traditions. According to him, statues were an imitation of un-Islamic cultures and also involved wasting people's money. Most notably, Rida vigorously campaigned against the statue-erection of the Egyptian nationalist leader <a href="Mustafa%20Kamil%20Pasha">Mustafa Kamil Pasha</a>.
Anti-colonialism.
Rida focused on the relative weakness of Muslim societies vis-à-vis <a href="Western%20colonialism">Western colonialism</a>, blaming <a href="Sufi">Sufi</a> excesses, the blind imitation of the past ("<a href="taqlid">taqlid</a>"), the stagnation of the "<a href="ulama">ulama</a>", and the resulting failure to achieve progress in science and technology. He held that these flaws could be alleviated by a return to what he saw as the true principles of Islam albeit interpreted ("<a href="ijtihad">ijtihad</a>") to suit modern realities. This alone could, he believed, save Muslims from subordination to the colonial powers.
Tunisian Naturalisation issue.
In 1923, the French government had enacted a law for easier citizenship access to Tunisians. Responding to a query from <a href="French%20protectorate%20of%20Tunisia">Tunisia</a> in 1924, Rashid Riḍā ruled that Muslims who naturalize are <a href="Apostasy%20in%20Islam">apostates</a>; since they are guilty of giving preference to non-Muslim system of law. In 1932, he would issue another "<a href="fatwa">fatwa</a>" declaring the naturalized Tunisians as "enemies of Allah and His Prophet" and forbade them from being married or buried in Muslim cemeteries.
When <a href="French%20Third%20Republic">France</a> eased access for <a href="French%20nationality%20law">French citizenship</a> for the <a href="French%20protectorate%20of%20Tunisia">French Protectorate of Tunisia</a> in 1933, Rida backed the <a href="Tunisian%20naturalization%20issue">anti-naturalization</a> protests. In line with the Salafi doctrine of <a href="Al-Wala%27%20wal-Bara%27">"Al Wala wal Bara"</a>, Rida issued a "fatwa" prohibiting the acquisition of citizenship of the colonial power, stating that it was apostasy from Islam:"By acquiring such citizenship, he agrees to give his money and his life to fighting Muslims if his country calls on him to do so... One who acquires such citizenship considers it permissible to violate these precepts, and doing so is universally agreed to be kufr(disbelief)."
On Freemasonry.
Rashid Rida advanced anti-Semitic conspiracies which would later become popular across the Arab world and various Islamist movements. In Rida's worldview, <a href="Freemasonry">Freemasonry</a> was invented by Jews to plot against world nations. Rida's early mentors Afghani and Abduh used to have close relations with <a href="Freemasonry">Freemasonry</a>. Afghani had arrived in Egypt in 1871 with the mission to combat what he perceived as the threat of European imperialism. For al-Afghani, freemasonry was a means of shattering "the towering edifices of injustice, tyranny, and oppression" in Egypt. Afghani had utilised Freemasonry as an organizational base for subversive activities against the Egyptian ruler, <a href="Isma%27il%20Pasha">Khedive Isma'il</a>. The political faction later founded by Afghani, "al-Hizb al Watanlal-Hurr" ('The Free National Party') would play a major role in removing Ismail Pasha from the throne and bringing <a href="Tewfik%20Pasha">Tawfiq Pasha</a> as the Khedive. In these efforts, Afghani was also aided by his disciples such as Muhammad Abduh whom he persuaded to join Freemasonry. Through these associations, Abduh was able to establish contacts with Tawfiq Pasha and other leaders of Egypt. In his later life, however, Abduh would distance himself from his past associations with freemasonry. Afghani and Abduh would later withdraw from Freemasonry due to political disputes. Years later, Rida would ask 'Abduh why he and Afghani had become Masons, 'Abduh replied that it was for a "political and social purpose". Rida pointed to Abduh that the objective of the Masons was "the destruction of all the religions." His attitudes towards <a href="Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD%20Faith">Baháʼí Faith</a> were also negative.
From the turn of nineteenth century, Rida's "Al-Manar" periodical would regularly feature anti-semitic articles linking Jews and Freemasons who eagerly sought the exploitation of "all nations’ wealth for its own benefit". By the 1930s, Rida would also promote the ideas of <a href="The%20Protocols%20of%20the%20Elders%20of%20Zion">Protocols of the Elders of Zion</a>. Conspiracy theories accusing Freemasons and Jews of seeking to topple the existing order through secret machinations featured regularly in "Al-Manar". In his articles, Rida maintained that the Jews created Freemasonry and through it orchastrated the Young Turk revolution in the Ottoman Empire in 1908 and <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution of 1789</a> and manipulated the <a href="Bolsheviks">Bolsheviks</a> against the <a href="Tsar">Czar</a>. By 1910, Rashid Rida believed that Ottoman Empire had fallen under a Zionist-Masonic influence due to the <a href="Young%20Turk%20Revolution">Young Turk Revolution</a>. Adopting a narrative of a grand, <a href="Jewish%20conspiracy">global Jewish conspiracy</a>; Rida described that the Jews, oppressed by the <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic Church</a>, had orchestrated through the Freemasons the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a>, <a href="1905%20Russian%20Revolution">1905 Russian Revolution</a> and the Young Turk Revolution. According to Rida, the revolution of Young Turks was a Jewish response to the Ottoman Empire's rejection of Jewish ambitions to regain possession of their temple in Jerusalem and surrounding regions to reestablish their kingdom. Rida argued that Jews wielded immense influence over the <a href="Committee%20of%20Union%20and%20Progress">Committee of Union</a> and the treasury of the Ottoman Empire. As early as 1908, he had alleged about a Zionist plan to purchase <a href="Palestine%20%28region%29">Palestine</a> from the Freemasons in Turkish leadership and called upon Arabs to resist this plan by force. By March 1914, Rida believed that the Zionists had already managed to convince the Committee of Union and Progress to support Jewish rule in Palestine as a buffer against the Arabs and as a means to divide them.
According to Rida, the term ‘Freemason’ itself refers to the re-construction of the <a href="Solomon%27s%20Temple">temple of Solomon</a>. In his articles, Rida emphasized that although the founders of Freemasonry were Jews and Christians, Jews led and dominated the movement. Rida viewed freemasonry as a Jewish invention and one of the tools of Jews in their bid to re-establish a Jewish state and rebuild Solomon's temple in <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>. They dominated the Freemasons, concealing the ultimate objective of establishing a Jewish state and overthrowing the religious governments in Europe, Russia, and Turkey, where Islamic law was replaced by a secularist government. Although the Jesuits were able to thwart their influence in Catholic countries, Jews succeeded in establishing Bolshevism in Russia and secularise Turkey. Explaining his beliefs, Rida wrote in his famous 1929 article "Revolution in Palestine: Its Causes and Consequences"("Thawrat Filastin: Asbabuha wa nata’ijuha") in "Al-Manar": "It is an established hidden truth that the Society of the Freemasons, which has control over the religious establishments and governments of the European, Turkish and Russian countries is a plot of the Jews, and they possess the greatest authority in it, though this is hidden from most of its members, ... and it is one of the wonders of the plotting and potential of the Jews... that their final political goal is the establishment of a divine Jewish State in the mold of the State of Israel which David established and which was improved by Solomon, the builder of the Jewish Temple atop Mount Zion in Jerusalem. Owing to this, they named it the Society of Freemasons... and most of the members of this society are ignorant about the correct reason for this naming. So has there been found anyone stranger in the world, than the group which destroys the religious authority of others to establish the same thing for their themselves, and mocks the gentiles for many generations for what they neither know nor understand?"
Reception.
Despite some un-conventional stances held by Rida, his works and in particular his magazine "<a href="al-Manar">al-Manar</a>" spread throughout the <a href="Muslim%20world">Muslim world</a>; influencing many individuals including the popular Salafi writer <a href="Muhammad%20Nasiruddin%20al-Albani">Muhammad Nasiruddin al-Albani</a>.
The status of Rida and his works, are a matter of contention amongst some contemporary <a href="Salafi%20movement%23Purists">purist Salafis</a>. Unlike the Purist Salafis, Rashid Rida considered rulers who legislated man-made laws contrary to "<a href="sharia">sharia</a>" to be guilty of "<a href="Kufr">kufr akbar</a>" (major disbelief). According to Rida, Muslims are obliged to force such rulers to annul such laws or overthrow them. If they are unable to do that, their lands can no longer be considered "<a href="Divisions%20of%20the%20world%20in%20Islam">Dar-al-Islam</a>" (abode of Islam). Owing to this, some present-day Salafi Purists criticise Rida for straying from <a href="Political%20quietism%20in%20Islam%23Quietism%20among%20Salafists">quietist</a> Salafi principles. The pro-government <a href="Madkhalism">Madkhali</a> Salafists condemn Rida for his influence on <a href="Salafi%20movement%23Salafi%20activists">Salafi-activists</a>, <a href="Islamism">Islamists</a> and <a href="Salafi%20jihadism">Salafi-Jihadists</a>. However, other Salafi scholars such as Albani, while critiquing his mistakes on "Hadeeth" sciences, praises Rida and his works generally. Praising Rashid Rida and his scholarly contributions, Al-Albani stated:"As-Sayid Muhammad Rasheed Rida (may God have mercy upon him), has a great virtue upon the Islamic world in a general form and upon the Salafis in a particular form, and this turns to him being a rare caller who spread the "Salafi Manhaj" in all the corners of the world through his magazine "Al-Manar", and he performed a great struggle for which he is thanked, and it is hoped that his reward will be enshrined for him with his Lord. In addition to being a caller to following the approach of the "Salaf us Salih" in what they were upon in terms of belief, thought and behavior, he also had a keen interest in discerning the authentic and weak hadiths... Sayyid Muhammad Rasheed Rida had a great interest in the science of Hadith, to the extent of assisting his scholarly, societal and political stances... his magazine "Al-Manar..." became a good nucleus that drew the attention of Muslims to take care of the hadiths of the Prophet Peace be upon him."
Islamic Political Theory.
Rashid Rida is widely regarded as one of "the ideological forefathers" of contemporary <a href="Islamism">Islamist</a> movements. Rida's ideas were foundational to the development of the modern "<a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic state</a>". He "was an important link between classical theories of the <a href="caliphate">caliphate</a>, such as <a href="al-Mawardi">al-Mawardi's</a>, and 20th-century notions of the Islamic state". While rejecting <a href="Secularism">secularist</a> calls for separation of religion and state with regards to <a href="Islam">Islam</a>, Rida nevertheless contended that those who engage in defence of Islam, its propagation and its teaching should not engage in politics, in line with orthodox <a href="Sunni%20Islam">Sunni doctrine</a>.
Rashid Rida preceded <a href="Abul%20Ala%20Maududi">Abul Ala Maududi</a>, <a href="Sayyid%20Qutb">Sayyid Qutb</a>, and later <a href="Islamist">Islamist</a>s in declaring adherence to "<a href="Sharia">Sharia</a>" (Islamic law) as essential for Islamic rulers, saying
Koran 5:44 applies to '...whomsoever thinks it distasteful to rule in accordance with the just rules which God sent down, and does not rule by them because he has different views, or because he has worldly interests. According to these verses, they are unbelievers; because true faith requires obedience. Obedience requires deeds, and is not consistent with omission' 
Historical Analysis.
The corruption and tyranny of Muslim rulers (<a href="caliphs">caliphs</a>, "<a href="sultan">sultan</a>s", etc.) throughout history was a central theme in Rida's criticisms. Rida, however, celebrated the rule of <a href="Muhammad%20in%20Islam">Muhammad</a> and the <a href="Rightly%20Guided%20Caliphs">Rightly Guided Caliphs</a>, and leveled his attacks at subsequent rulers who could not maintain Muhammad's example. He also criticized the Islamic scholars ("<a href="ulama">ulama</a>") for compromising their integrity - and the integrity of the Islamic law ("<a href="sharia">sharia</a>") they were meant to uphold - by associating with corrupt worldly powers. Rida believed that throughout <a href="History%20of%20Islam">Islamic history</a>, the feudal monarchs and the depraved "Ulema" classes had disfigured the ideal <a href="caliphate">caliphate</a> system, leading to social chaos and institutionalising corruption of authoritarian rulers. He expounded the revival of an ideal, veritable “<a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic state</a>” political system, and reverse this status-quo.
Arab Pre-eminence.
Rashid Rida also believed that the awakening of <a href="Arabs">Arabs</a> was an important prerequisite for Islamic Renaissance. Since it was during the early days of Arab power that Islamic power reached its pinnacle; only the Arab nation could the restore the might of early Islam. By constantly stressing on Arab pre-eminence; Rida pointed out that only Arabs can take up the "historic mission" of Islamic Unity.
Rida viewed <a href="Arabic">Arabic</a> language as the common medium that unites <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a> of all nations and promoted Arabic as an integral pillar of his reform efforts. Issuing a "<a href="Fatwa">Fatwa</a>" stipulating that knowledge of Arabic is obligatory on every Muslim, Rida wrote in "<a href="Al-Man%C4%81r%20%28magazine%29">Al-Manar</a>": "We have stated more than once that knowledge of Arabic is obligatory upon every Muslim, because understanding the religion, establishing its rituals and fulfilling its obligations all depend on understanding this language, and cannot be valid without it... The <a href="Ajam">non-Arabs</a> who entered Islam in the early period hastened to learn Arabic in order to understand the "Qur’aan" and "Sunnah" and to form bonds through the language without which the unity of the "ummah" cannot be achieved. The "<a href="Companions%20of%20the%20Prophet">Sahaabah</a>" used to address the people in Arabic in every land that they conquered, and it was not long before the language of the lands that they entered became Arabic, due to the influence of the spirit of Islam... The difference in languages that we see today among Muslims is one of the most serious bad effects of politics... We cannot rely on any religious reform in India or elsewhere in the Muslim world, unless Arabic is taught from the primary stage and is made the language of knowledge."
"Jihad".
Rashid Rida believed that <a href="Islam">Islam</a> prescribed armed "<a href="Jihad">Jihad</a>" as a binding duty upon all capable male Muslims; not only to defend the religion but also to bring non-Muslims into the fold of the Islamic faith. However, since the obligation of "<a href="Jihad">Jihad</a>" cannot be performed unless they are strong, their immediate task was to acquire the sciencitific and technical prowess first, inorder to fulfill the duty of "Jihad". While upholding "Jihad" as a necessary duty, Rida nonetheless distinguished between wars to spread Islam ("Jihad al-Talab") and wars to defend Islam ("Jihad al-Daf"'). While the latter are always obligatory; Jihad to expand Islam into non-Muslim territories ("<a href="Dar%20al-Harb">Dar al-Harb</a>") is not obligatory unless Muslims are not allowed to live according to "<a href="sharia">sharia</a>" or unless Islamic "<a href="Dawah">Da'wa</a>"(preaching) efforts were hampered by the non-Muslim state.
"Jahiliyya" and "Hakimiyya".
Rashid Rida revived Ibn Taymiyya's concept of "<a href="Jahiliyyah">Jahiliyya</a>", a "<a href="Quran">Qur'anic</a>" term that denoted the ignorance of <a href="pre-Islamic%20Arabia">pre-Islamic Arabia</a>. He applied this concept to Muslim lands of his own era and charged the ruling secular authorities with <a href="Apostasy%20in%20Islam">apostasy</a> for submitting to man-made laws and substituting <a href="Sharia">Islamic laws</a>, in the same manner Ibn Taymiyya <a href="Takfir">ex-communicated</a> the <a href="Tatars">Tatars</a>. Rida argued that only "salafiyya" Islam, "an Islam purged of impurities and Western influences", could save Muslims from colonial subordination and "Jahiliyya". He detested the rulers who substituted Western laws for "sharia" and "<a href="takfir">takfir</a>ed" them stating: "[the secular rulers]... abolish supposedly distasteful penalties such as cutting off the hands of thieves or stoning adulterers and prostitutes. They replace them with man-made laws and penalties. He who does that has undeniably become an infidel.”
Rashid Rida believed that Islamic law was flexible enough to remain relevant for all eras and was staunchly opposed to influences of foreign law-codes. The <a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic state</a> is to be based on "Hakimiyya" (“sovereignty of Allah”) and it "does not recognize the sovereignty of the people, and the state denies people’s legislative power”. Muslim politicians must engage with the state's social, political, economic and process of the state according to the sources of Islamic law.
Explaining the four basic, agreed upon sources of Islamic law; Rashid Rida wrote:"the [well-known] sources of legislation in Islam are four: the Qur'an, the Sunnah, the consensus of the ummah and ijtihad undertaken by competent jurists"
"Shura".
Throughout his works, Rashid Rida emphasized that Islamic law ("Sharia") was intended to be a comprehensive legal structure for the society. He promoted a restoration of the Caliphate for Islamic unity, through '"<a href="shura">shura</a>"'". In theology, his reformist ideas, like those of Abduh, were "based on the argument that:
<a href="shari%27a">shari'a</a> consists of "<a href="Ibadah">`ibadat</a>" (worship) and "<a href="mu%27amalat">mu'amalat</a>" (social relations). Human reason has little scope in the former and Muslims should adhere to the dictates of the <a href="Qur%27an">Qur'an</a> and hadith. The laws governing "mu'amalat" should conform to Islamic ethics but on specific points may be continually reassessed according to changing conditions of different generations and societies.Rida's <a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic state</a> envisioned a representative government, which he compared to be "a sort of a <a href="republic">republic</a>", that upholds "Shura" (Islamic consultative system) in political life. The "<a href="Khalifa">Khalifa</a>" has no superiority in <a href="Sharia">law</a> over his subjects; and his duty is only to execute the religious law("<a href="sharia">sharia</a>") and act according to national interests. The Caliph must uphold truth, social justice and the rule of law; cleanse "<a href="Bid%CA%BBah">bid'a</a>" (innovations), eliminate oppression and consult his advisors in issues not verifiable by the "<a href="Quran">Quran</a>" and "<a href="Sunnah">Sunnah</a>". The caliph is not a "<a href="Ismah">Ma'sum</a>"(infallible) or a source of revelation and was responsible for all his deeds. The nation has the right to depose the caliph, for valid reasons. Every member of the "<a href="Ummah">Ummah</a>" had a right to question the Caliph for his errors. The best possible way to bring about a strong caliphate was through a detailed application "of the rules of the "Shariah"." One of these rules is involved the appointment of "<a href="Ahl%20al-hall%20wal-aqd">ahl al-hal wa-l 'aqd</a>" (the group who loosen and bind), a group of Muslim representatives who have the right to take council("mushabaha") with a Caliph as well as the power to both appoint and remove him of behalf of the "Ummah." Since the state uses Islamic law as its guiding principle, the "<a href="Ulama">Ulema</a>" were not only responsible for the sacred mission of reforming the society, but also responsible for correcting the monarch, by holding him accountable to "Sharia". The "<a href="Faq%C4%ABh">Fuqaha</a>" were also to engage in "<a href="Ijtihad">Ijtihad</a>" by referring to the Scriptures, and evalute contemporary conditions to enhance the vitality of the law. In a jibe against his theological opponents, Rida also remarked that their forsaking of "Ijtihad" had sunk Muslims into ignorance and "<a href="westernization">westernization</a> and <a href="atheism">atheism</a>."
The two major books outlining the Political Doctrines of Rashid Rida are: i) "Al-Khilafa aw al-Imama al-ʿUzma" (""The Caliphate or the Grand Imamate") ii) "'al-Waḥī al-Muḥammadī" ("The Muhammadan Revelation"")
"The Caliphate or the Grand Imamate" (1922).
Al-Khilafa aw al-Imama al-ʿUzma () is an influential treatise written by Rashid Rida in 1922, during the aftermath of the <a href="Abolition%20of%20the%20Ottoman%20sultanate">Turkish Abolition of the Ottoman Sultanate</a>. The treatise outlined a comprehensive <a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic state</a> theory by taking precedence from classical <a href="Sunni%20Islam">Sunni</a> doctrines; especially those of <a href="Al-Mawardi">Al-Mawardi</a>. The treatise would become an authoritative reference for modern <a href="Islamist">Islamist</a> movements.
"The Muhammadan Revelation" (1933).
Rashid Riḍā's final substantial treatise "The Muhammadan Revelation" ("al-Waḥī al-Muḥammadī"), published in 1933, was a <a href="manifesto">manifesto</a> in which he proclaimed that Islam is the only savior for the deteriorating <a href="Western%20world">West</a>. Insisting that <a href="Islam">Islam</a> called for the Brotherhood of all people, opposing all forms of racist hierarchies that were responsible for the <a href="World%20War%20I">World War</a> and the corrupted <a href="League%20of%20Nations">League of Nations</a>, Rashid Rida presented a Universal Islamic Order as a substitute for the crumbling Wilsonian system.
Articulating the Islamic vision of <a href="Islah">Reformation</a> for <a href="human">human</a>ity, Rashid Rida wrote:"When Islam came into the world, humankind was widely divided; on the basis of origin, color, language, geography, religion, tribal affiliation, government, and politics. Moreover, on the basis of anyone of these differences, humans went to war... Then Islam came along and called out loud and clear, calling humankind to a common humanity, and binding them to it so that they would no longer see their differences as reasons for enmity and aggression... Islam directed its call to all of humankind, and within the first century of the Muhammadan Revelation all the peoples of the civilized world had heard about Islam, so that from the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic</a> to the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific</a> people were becoming Muslims in droves. Had it not been for the aberrations in those who governed the Muslims, had it not been for their tyranny and love of power, and had it not been for the ignorance of many of those whose conversions to Islam were incomplete, the world today would be a different place, and <a href="Arabic">Arabic</a> would be spoken everywhere. But, finally, the truth will always prevail."
Rashid Rida blamed the horrors of the First World War on <a href="European%20nationalism">European nationalism</a> and <a href="White%20supremacy">racial obsession</a>. Introducing <a href="Islam">Islam</a> as the solution for <a href="World%20peace">World peace</a>, Rida explained the Five important Islamic teachings on "<a href="Jihad">Jihad</a>":
According to Rida, <a href="Islam">Islam</a> is a comprehensive religion, which, in addition to dealing with <a href="Islamic%20ethics">ethics</a> and <a href="Zuhd%20in%20Islam">spirituality</a>; also elaborated on leadership, politics and government. The <a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic state</a> symbolised "the greatest political reform" brought forth by the "<a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>" in an age when all of humanity were shackled by various manifestations of <a href="Tyrant">tyranny</a>. Taking the "<a href="Rashidun">Khulafa Rashidun</a>" as the exemplar models, Rashid Rida elaborated on the basic features of an Islamic government:"Rule, in Islam, is for the people, the "ummah"; its form is to be "shura", or mutual consultation; and its leader is to the "imam" or "khalifah", the one who implements the "Shari'ah". The "<a href="ummah">ummah</a>", in turn, is to determine whether the "imam" stays or goes... Those in authority are those who are most competent in finding solutions to issues, whose opinions are informed, who have the best interests of the ummah in mind, and who enjoy the confidence and support of the "ummah"."
Influence on Islamists.
The Islamic political doctrines of Rashid Rida would deeply influence many future <a href="Islamism">Islamists</a> like <a href="Hassan%20al-Banna">Hasan al-Banna</a>, <a href="Sayyid%20Qutb">Sayyid Qutb</a>, etc. as well as subsequent <a href="Islamic%20fundamentalism">fundamentalist</a> movements across the <a href="Arab%20world">Arab world</a>. <a href="Egyptians">Egyptian</a> school teacher Hasan al-Banna, was highly influenced by Rashid Rida's "<a href="Salafi%20movement">Salafiyya</a>" movement as well his <a href="Pan-Islamism">Pan-Islamist</a> activities through socio-political means to re-generate an <a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic state</a>. Continuing Rida's work, Al-Banna would go on to establish the <a href="Muslim%20Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a>, a mass political party which sought to establish an Islamic state in <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, within the existing constitutional framework. The movement demanded the Egyptian government to recognize "<a href="Sharia">Sharia</a>" as the supreme source of law and remove the European law codes.
The <a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic State</a> Theory of Rashid Rida was also adopted by <a href="Osama%20bin%20Laden">Usama Bin Laden</a> and <a href="Ayman%20al-Zawahiri">Ayman al Zawahiri</a>. Throughout their references of "Islamic State" and "<a href="Caliphate">Caliphate</a>", Bin Laden and Zawahiri followed the terminology as advocated by Rashid Rida and later embraced by Hasan al-Banna; which differentiated between an Islamic State and the Caliphate. In contrast to other Islamist movements like <a href="Hizb%20ut-Tahrir">Hizb ut-Tahrir</a> who believed that a Caliphate is the only valid government; the two <a href="Al-Qaeda">Al-Qaeda</a> leaders believed in the legitimacy of multiple Islamic national states referring to them as Emirates, such as the <a href="Afghanistan">Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan</a> and <a href="Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> until 1990s when it lost legitimacy according to Bin Laden.
In developing the pan-Islamist model of <a href="Jamal%20al-Din%20al-Afghani">Afghani</a>, Rida had specifically admired the model of the "<a href="Rashidun">Khulafa Rashidun</a>", and resurrected <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya's</a> concept of "<a href="Jahiliyyah">Jahiliyya</a>". Moving towards a militant and conservative sphere of <a href="Islamic%20revival">revivalist</a> teachings, Rida condemned the secular authorities of his era to be <a href="Apostasy%20in%20Islam">apostates</a>; just like the <a href="Mongol%20Empire">Mongols</a> during the era of Ibn Taymiyya. Furthermore, he condemned the state-backed scholars for neglecting the revival of the traditions and values of early eras of Islam. Rida's insistence that only an <a href="Muslim%20world">Islamic world</a> completely free of Western influences could escape the colonial noose and the state of "Jahiliyya", set the foundations of future <a href="Salafi%20jihadism">Salafi-Jihadist</a> ideologies. Rida's strategy to establish an Islamic State is also believed to have influenced the <a href="Islamic%20State%20of%20Iraq%20and%20the%20Levant">Islamic State of Iraq and Levant</a> in their 2014 <a href="Abu%20Bakr%20al-Baghdadi%23Declaration%20of%20a%20caliphate">declaration of Caliphate in Mosul</a>.
Legacy.
Muhammad Rashid Rida is considered by Salafis as an erudite scholarly authority for contemporary reference. Salafi scholar Muhammad 'Abdullah Salman authored a book in his praise, titled, "al-Shaykh Rashid Rida al-Musleh al-Salafi"(al-Shaykh Rashid Rida the Salafi Reformer). Rida's efforts were instrumental in fostering the modern trans-national network of Salafi scholarship across the world. Early Salafi "<a href="ulema">ulema</a>" of <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> would built extensive relations with Wahhabi scholars through education, travel, religious gatherings, etc. These included Muhammad Hamid al-Fiqi, ʿAbd al-Razzaq Hamzah, ʿAbd al-Zahir Abu al-Samh, etc. who were the pupils of Rida. These "ʿulama" would continue writing against innovations and various Sufi practices within the theological framework laid down by <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyyah</a>, the Najdis, and Rashid Rida. Their organisation, "Ansar al-Sunnah al Muhammadiyyah" would become the bastion of Salafiyya school in Egypt. Apart from the Purist Salafis, <a href="Salafi%20movement%23Salafi%20Activists">Salafi activists</a> ("harakis") also look up to Rida's works to build a revivalist platform focused on Islamic socio-political and cultural reforms ("<a href="Islah">Islah</a>") with a long-term objective to establish an <a href="Islamic%20state">Islamic state</a>. Prominent figures in this rival camp include Abu Hanieh, <a href="Safar%20al-Hawali">Safar Al-Hawali</a>, <a href="Abu%20Qatada">Abu Qatada</a>, <a href="Muhammad%20Surur">Muhammad Surur</a>, <a href="Abd%20al-Rahman%20Abd%20al-Khaliq">Abdurrahman Abdulkhaliq</a>, etc. Abu Qatada and Abu Hanieh established a new movement known as "Ahl Al-Sunnah Wal Jama’a" based in Jordan and published "al-Manar" magazine named after Rashid Rida's popular monthly.
The influential <a href="Salafi%20movement%23Salafi%20activists">activist-Salafi</a> organisation Islamic Assembly of North America (IANA), which played a crucial role in the spread of Salafism across <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, drew inspiration from Muhammad Rashid Rida. The official publication of the organisation was a magazine titled "Al-Manar al-Jadid" (“the New Lighthouse”) in honour of Rashid Rida's legacy. The magazine's prologue was copied verbatim from Rida's original 19th century text; believing that the Muslim community continued to face "the same tribulations" as during Rida's era. The organisation included notable scholars and figures like <a href="Bilal%20Philips">Bilal Philips</a>, Muhammad Adly, Jamal Zarabozo, Abdel Rahman al-Dosari, etc. After 9/11, IANA would be subject to intense federal scrutiny. As a result of this policy in the post 9/11 period, IANA was eventually forced to disband; many members were deported, and some others, like <a href="Ali%20al-Tamimi">Ali al-Timimi</a>, were jailed.
Salafi scholar <a href="Muhammad%20Nasiruddin%20al-Albani">Nasir al Din Al Albani</a> considered Rashid Rida to be his mentor. As an avid reader of "Al-Manar", Albani embraced key Traditionalist Salafi ideas through Rida's works and adopted Rida as his intellectual father. For Albani, Riḍā exemplified the standard of how to look to "<a href="Hadith">ḥadith</a>" for reviving the <a href="Ummah">Muslim community</a>. Crediting Rida for his turn to Salafism and interest in <a href="Hadith%20studies">"hadith" sciences</a>, Albani stated: "Whatever I have concerning my orientation towards Salafism first, and to the discernment of weak ḥadīth reports second, the credit for this goes to the sayyid Muḥammad Rashīd Riḍā..." 
In his treatise "The Exoneration" written in response to <a href="Sayyed%20Imam%20Al-Sharif">Sayyid Imam Al-Sharif</a>, Salafi-jihadist leader <a href="Ayman%20al-Zawahiri">Ayman al Zawahiri</a> cited the anti-colonial fatwa of Rashid Rida (against <a href="Tunisian%20naturalization%20issue">French naturalization</a>) to argue that a Muslim who applies for Western citizenship by his own choice is guilty of "kufr"(disbelief) or close to "kufr". Islamic scholar <a href="Yusuf%20al-Qaradawi">Yusuf al-Qaradawi</a> described Rida as "the true "<a href="Mujaddid">Mujaddid</a>" of Islam of his time" and views him as the most prominent scholar who advocated traditionalism in contemporary Islamic history. Qaradawi described Rida's thought as a "lighthouse" that "guided the ship of Islam in modern history".
Albani's son ‘Abd Allah praised Rashid Rida as ""<a href="muhaddith">muhaddith</a> Misr"" (the ḥadīth scholar of Egypt). The Egyptian Salafi hadith scholar <a href="Ahmad%20Muhammad%20Shakir">Ahmad Shakir</a> conferred the title of "<a href="Hujjat%20al-Islam">Hujjat al-Islam</a>" to Rashid Rida and extolled his <a href="Quran">Qur'anic</a> commentary, "<a href="Tafsir%20al-Manar">Tafsir al-Manar</a>" as a "real defense of religion" in the contemporary era, encouraging everyone to read as well as spread his "<a href="Tafsir">Tafsir</a>". Prominent Saudi scholar <a href="Muhammad%20ibn%20al-Uthaymeen">Ibn 'Uthaymeen</a> listed Rashid Rida as his chief source of scholarly influence alongside <a href="Ibn%20Taymiyyah">Ibn Taymiyya</a> and commended Rida as an exemplar scholar of "<a href="sharia">sharia</a>" who had the combined knowledge of religious sciences as well political and economic affairs.
<a href="Grand%20Imam%20of%20al-Azhar">Grand Imam of al-Azhar</a>, <a href="Mustafa%20al-Maraghi">Mustafa al-Maraghi</a> praised Rida as the champion of Salafi thought during his funeral saying:
"Al-Sayyid Rashid triumphed and his supporters and disciples became many, while there were once few supporters and disciples... and clouds of ignorance and falsehood were wiped out of their hearts. He didn't have any new principle in Islam, but his principle was the principle of the entire ‘"ulama"’ of the "Salaf", i.e., to return in judgment to God and His Messenger... and his principle was also that of the ‘"ulama"’ of the "Salaf" in choosing rules appropriate for the time and beneficial for nations in issues of "ijtihad and his principle was that of the ‘ulama’ of the Salaf" in everything related to Divine attributes and the issues related to the last day, so he was a "Salafi" Sunni man who disliked "taqlid" and propagated "ijtihad", seeing it an obligation upon himself and upon everyone capable."
